title: Abel-Ruffini Theorem
description: Galois's profound theorem that there is no general algebraic solution to polynomial equations of degree five or higher, connecting field theory to group theory through the unsolvability of the symmetric group S5.

title: Arithmetic Mean - Geometric Mean Inequality
description: The AM-GM Inequality: For non-negative real numbers, the arithmetic mean is always greater than or equal to the geometric mean, with equality if and only if all numbers are equal.

title: Impossibility of Trisecting an Angle
description: The classical impossibility proof that an arbitrary angle cannot be trisected using only compass and straightedge, along with the impossibility of doubling the cube. These problems puzzled mathematicians for over 2000 years until Wantzel's 1837 proof.

title: Area of a Circle
description: The area of a circle with radius r is πr². One of the most fundamental formulas in geometry, known since Archimedes proved it around 250 BCE.

title: Sum of an Arithmetic Series
description: Gauss's formula for the sum of the first n natural numbers: 1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2. A classic result with a famous anecdote about young Gauss.

title: The Ballot Problem
description: In an election where candidate A receives p votes and candidate B receives q votes (p > q), the probability that A leads throughout the counting is (p-q)/(p+q).

title: The Basel Problem: Sum of Reciprocal Squares
description: The sum of reciprocals of squares equals π²/6. Euler's famous 1734 solution to the Basel Problem launched his illustrious career.

title: Bertrand's Postulate
description: For every integer n > 1, there exists a prime p such that n < p ≤ 2n. Conjectured by Bertrand (1845), first proved by Chebyshev (1852), with an elegant elementary proof by Erdős (1932).

title: Bezout's Identity
description: For any integers a, b, there exist x, y such that ax + by = gcd(a,b). Fundamental to number theory.

title: The Binomial Theorem
description: (x + y)^n = Σ C(n,k) x^k y^(n-k). One of the most fundamental results in algebra and combinatorics.

title: Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. The rank of an elliptic curve equals the order of vanishing of its L-function at s=1.

title: The Birthday Problem
description: The surprising probability that in a group of just 23 people, there's a greater than 50% chance that two share a birthday. A classic example of how probability defies intuition.

title: Borsuk-Ulam Theorem
description: For any continuous function from the n-sphere to n-dimensional Euclidean space, there exist antipodal points with the same image. The 'weather theorem' that guarantees antipodal points on Earth with identical temperature and pressure.

title: Brouwer Fixed Point Theorem
description: Every continuous function from a closed ball to itself has at least one fixed point. A cornerstone of topology with profound applications in economics, game theory, and differential equations.

title: Buffon's Needle Problem
description: If a needle of length l is dropped onto a floor with parallel lines spaced distance d apart, the probability it crosses a line is 2l/(pi*d).

title: Cantor's Diagonalization Theorem
description: Cantor's elegant 1891 proof that the real numbers are uncountable, using the famous diagonal argument to show no enumeration can list all infinite binary sequences.

title: Cantor's Theorem
description: For any set A, there is no surjection from A to its power set P(A). This establishes that |A| < |P(A)| = 2^|A|, proving the hierarchy of infinite cardinalities.

title: Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality
description: |⟨u,v⟩| ≤ ‖u‖·‖v‖. Fundamental to functional analysis and quantum mechanics.

title: Cayley-Hamilton Theorem
description: Every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial. If A is an n×n matrix with characteristic polynomial p(λ) = det(λI - A), then p(A) = 0.

title: Central Limit Theorem
description: The sum of a large number of independent random variables converges to a normal distribution. This proof combines the classical characteristic function approach with an algebraic topological interpretation of the Gaussian as an attractor.

title: Ceva's Theorem
description: Ceva's Theorem (Wiedijk's #61): Given a triangle ABC with cevians AD, BE, CF, these lines are concurrent if and only if (AF/FB) * (BD/DC) * (CE/EA) = 1

title: Chinese Remainder Theorem (Constructive)
description: For pairwise coprime moduli, there exists a unique solution to any system of congruences. Includes the classic Sunzi problem: find n where n = 2 (mod 3), n = 3 (mod 5), n = 2 (mod 7). Answer: 23.

title: Collatz Conjecture for Structured Values
description: The Collatz sequence reaches 1 for powers of 2 and numbers of the form 2^k * m where m reaches 1. Verified cases include 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, and 27 (which takes 111 steps).

title: Formula for the Number of Combinations
description: The number of ways to choose k elements from a set of n elements is C(n,k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!). This fundamental formula in combinatorics counts the number of k-element subsets of an n-element set.

title: Independence of the Continuum Hypothesis
description: The Continuum Hypothesis is independent of ZFC set theory. Godel showed CH is consistent with ZFC; Cohen showed not-CH is also consistent.

title: Cramer's Rule
description: For Ax = b with det(A) ≠ 0, xᵢ = det(Aᵢ)/det(A) where Aᵢ has column i replaced by b.

title: De Moivre's Theorem
description: (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ). Connects powers of complex numbers to multiple angle formulas.

title: Denumerability of the Rationals
description: Cantor's proof that the rational numbers are countable: despite being dense in the reals, there exists a bijection between the natural numbers and the rationals.

title: The Derangements Formula
description: The number of permutations with no fixed points: D(n) = n! Σ(-1)^k/k!. The 'hat-check problem'.

title: Desargues's Theorem
description: Desargues's Theorem (Wiedijk's #87): If two triangles are in perspective from a point, then they are in perspective from a line, and conversely.

title: Descartes' Rule of Signs
description: The number of positive real roots of a polynomial is either equal to the number of sign changes in the coefficient sequence, or less than it by an even number.

title: Dirichlet's Theorem on Primes in Arithmetic Progressions
description: For any two positive coprime integers a and q, there are infinitely many primes congruent to a modulo q. This foundational result in analytic number theory uses Dirichlet characters and L-functions.

title: Dissection of Cubes
description: A cube cannot be dissected into a finite number of smaller cubes, all of different sizes.

title: Divisibility by 3 Rule
description: A natural number is divisible by 3 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 3. This ancient divisibility test works because 10 ≡ 1 (mod 3).

title: Transcendence of e
description: The number e = 2.71828... is transcendental: it is not a root of any polynomial with integer coefficients. The first number proven transcendental by Hermite.

title: Erdős Problem #1: Distinct Subset Sums
description: If A is a subset of {1,...,N} with n elements and all 2^n subset sums are distinct, then N >> 2^n. Erdős's 'first serious problem' (1931). OPEN with $500 prize.

title: Erdős #100: Point Sets with Restricted Distances
description: Let A be n points in ℝ² with all pairwise distances ≥ 1 and any two distinct distances differing by ≥ 1. Must the diameter be ≫ n? Known: n^(3/4) (Kanold), n/log n (Guth-Katz). Piepmeyer: 9 points with diameter < 5.

title: Erdős #1000: Generalized Totients and Diophantine Approximation
description: For an infinite sequence A = {n₁ < n₂ < ...}, define φ_A(k) as the count of m ≤ n_k such that m/n_k in lowest form has denominator different from all previous n_j. Does lim (1/N) Σ φ_A(k)/n_k = 0 for some A? Answer: YES (Haight), contrary to Erdős' expectation.

title: Erdős #1001: Diophantine Approximation Density
description: Let S(N,A,c) measure α ∈ (0,1) with |α - x/y| < A/y² for some N ≤ y ≤ cN, gcd(x,y)=1. Does lim S(N,A,c) exist? YES (Kesten-Sós). Formula: f(A,c) = 12A log(c)/π² in EST regime.

title: Erdős Problem #1002: Asymptotic Distribution of Weighted Fractional Sums
description: For 0 < α < 1, define f(α,n) = (1/log n) Σ (1/2 - {αk}). Does f(α,n) have an asymptotic distribution function? Kesten (1960) proved the two-parameter variant has Cauchy distribution, but the one-parameter case remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #1003: Consecutive Equal Totients
description: Are there infinitely many solutions to φ(n) = φ(n+1), where φ is the Euler totient function? Erdős conjectured yes, and made the stronger claim that φ(n) = φ(n+1) = ... = φ(n+k) has infinitely many solutions for every k ≥ 1.

title: Erdős #1004: Distinct Consecutive Totient Values
description: For c > 0, if x is large, does there exist n ≤ x such that φ(n+1), ..., φ(n+⌊(log x)^c⌋) are all distinct? EPS (1987) proved K ≤ n/exp(c(log n)^{1/3}).

title: Erdős Problem #1005: Farey Fractions and Similar Ordering
description: Let f(n) be the longest run of consecutive similarly ordered Farey fractions of order n. Estimate f(n) - is there c > 0 with f(n) = (c + o(1))n? Known: (1/12 - o(1))n ≤ f(n) ≤ n/4 + O(1).

title: Erdős Problem #1006: Robust Acyclic Orientations
description: Can every graph with girth > 4 be oriented so that there is no directed cycle, and reversing any single edge also creates no directed cycle? Disproved by Nešetřil-Rödl (1978) for all girths.

title: Erdős Problem #1007: Graph Dimension
description: What is the smallest number of edges in a graph with dimension 4? The answer is 9, achieved uniquely by K_{3,3}. Graph dimension is the minimum Euclidean dimension for unit-distance embedding.

title: Erdős Problem #1008: C₄-Free Subgraphs
description: Does every graph with m edges contain a C₄-free subgraph with ≫ m^{2/3} edges? Yes, proved by Conlon-Fox-Sudakov (2014). The exponent 2/3 is optimal, as shown by Folkman's counterexample K_{n,n²}.

title: Erdős Problem #1009: Edge-Disjoint Triangles Beyond Turán
description: For every c > 0, does there exist f(c) such that every graph with ⌊n²/4⌋ + k edges (k < cn) contains at least k - f(c) edge-disjoint triangles? SOLVED: Györi (1988) proved this with f(c) ≪ c².

title: Erdős Problem #1010: Triangle Supersaturation
description: For t < ⌊n/2⌋, every graph on n vertices with ⌊n²/4⌋ + t edges contains at least t·⌊n/2⌋ triangles. This quantifies the supersaturation phenomenon: how many triangles are forced when exceeding the Turán threshold.

title: Erdős Problem #1011: Triangles in Graphs with High Chromatic Number
description: Let f_r(n) be minimal such that every n-vertex graph with ≥ f_r(n) edges and χ ≥ r contains a triangle. Known: f_2(n) = ⌊n²/4⌋+1 (Turán), f_3(n) = ⌊(n-1)²/4⌋+2 (Erdős-Gallai). Asymptotic involves g(r) ~ r² log r. OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1012: Long Cycles in Dense Graphs
description: Let f(k) be such that every graph on n ≥ f(k) vertices with ≥ C(n-k-1,2) + C(k+2,2) + 1 edges has an (n-k)-cycle. Woodall (1972) proved f(k) ≤ 2k+3 and such graphs are pancyclic from 3 to n-k.

title: Erdős Problem #1015: Partitioning 2-Colored Complete Graphs
description: What is f(t), the minimum leftover vertices when partitioning any 2-colored Kₙ into vertex-disjoint monochromatic Kₜ's? Burr-Erdős-Spencer (1975) proved f(t) = R(t, t-1) + x where 0 ≤ x < t, showing f(t)^{1/t} → 4 (not 1) and f(t) is not O(t).

title: Erdős Problem #1017: Clique Partition of Graphs
description: Let f(n,k) be the min cliques to partition any graph with n vertices, k edges. Erdős-Goodman-Pósa proved f(n,k) ≤ n²/4. Can this be improved for k > n²/4? The K₄-free case is solved (Győri-Keszegh 2017).

title: Erdős Problem #1018: Non-Planar Subgraphs in Dense Graphs
description: For ε > 0, does every graph with n vertices and n^(1+ε) edges contain a non-planar subgraph on O_ε(1) vertices? Kostochka-Pyber (1988) proved yes: such graphs contain K₅ subdivisions on constantly many vertices.

title: Erdős Problem #1019: Saturated Planar Subgraphs in Dense Graphs
description: Does every graph on n vertices with ⌊n²/4⌋ + ⌊(n+1)/2⌋ edges contain a saturated planar graph with more than 3 vertices? Simonovits proved yes: such graphs must contain K₄ or C_l + 2K₁.

title: Erdős Problem #1020: The Erdős Matching Conjecture
description: Let f(n;r,k) be max edges in r-uniform hypergraph with no k independent edges. Conjecture: f(n;r,k) = max(C(rk-1,r), C(n,r)-C(n-k+1,r)). Solved for r=2,3. Upper bound: (k-1)C(n-1,r-1). OPEN for r≥4.

title: Erdős Problem #1021: Extremal Numbers for Bipartite Pair Graphs
description: For k ≥ 3, does there exist c_k > 0 such that ex(n, G_k) ≪ n^(3/2 - c_k)? Here G_k is the bipartite graph with k primary vertices and C(k,2) pair vertices. Even ex(n, G_k) = o(n^(3/2)) is unknown.

title: Erdős Problem #1022: Property B and Sparse Set Families
description: Is there c_t → ∞ such that if F is a family of sets of size ≥ t, and for every X there are < c_t|X| subsets of X in F, then F has property B (2-colorable)? Known: c_2 = 1 (Lovász 1968).

title: Erdős Problem #1023: Union-Free Families
description: Let F(n) be the max size of a family of subsets of {1,...,n} where no set is the union of other members. Is F(n) ~ c · 2^n / √n? YES: F(n) = C(n, n/2) ~ √(2/π) · 2^n / √n.

title: Erdős Problem #1024: Independent Sets in Linear Hypergraphs
description: Let f(n) be the minimum independence number guaranteed in every 3-uniform linear hypergraph on n vertices. Phelps-Rödl (1986) proved f(n) ≍ (n log n)^(1/2), refining Erdős's bounds n^(1/2) ≪ f(n) ≪ n^(2/3).

title: Erdős Problem #1025: Independent Sets in Pair Functions
description: Let f map pairs from {1,...,n} to {1,...,n} with f(x,y) ≠ x,y. Let g(n) be the minimum guaranteed independent set size. Erdős-Hajnal (1958) proved n^(1/3) ≪ g(n) ≪ (n log n)^(1/2). Spencer (1972) and Conlon-Fox-Sudakov (2016) determined g(n) = Θ(n^(1/2)).

title: Erdős Problem #1026: Monotonic Subsequence Sum Optimization
description: For a sequence of distinct reals, determine max sum over monotonic subsequences. The optimal constant is c = 1: maxMonotonicSum ≥ (1-o(1)) · totalSum/√n. This is a weighted Erdős-Szekeres theorem.

title: Erdős Problem #1027: Intersecting Sets and Property B
description: Let F be a family of at most c·2^n sets of size n, and X = ∪F. Must there exist ≫_c 2^|X| sets B ⊆ X that intersect every set in F yet contain none? YES (proved by Koishi Chan). Connection to Property B (2-chromatic families).

title: Erdős Problem #1028: Discrepancy of Sign Functions
description: Let H(n) = min_f max_X |∑_{x≠y∈X} f(x,y)| where f: pairs → {±1}. Erdős (1963) proved n/4 ≤ H(n) ≪ n^(3/2). Erdős-Spencer (1971) proved H(n) ≫ n^(3/2). Answer: H(n) = Θ(n^(3/2)).

title: Erdős Problem #1029: Ramsey Number Growth Rate
description: If R(k) is the diagonal Ramsey number, prove R(k)/(k·2^{k/2}) → ∞. Known bounds: (√2/e)·k·2^{k/2} ≤ R(k) ≤ C(2k-2,k-1). OPEN ($100 proof, $1000 disproof).

title: Erdős Problem #103: Incongruent Optimal Point Configurations
description: Let h(n) count the number of incongruent sets of n points in ℝ² that minimize diameter with d(x,y) ≥ 1 for all distinct x,y. Is h(n) → ∞?

title: Erdős Problem #1030: Ramsey Number Growth Rate
description: Prove the existence of c > 0 such that lim_{k→∞} R(k+1,k)/R(k,k) > 1+c. Solved by Burr-Erdős-Faudree-Schelp (1989) who proved R(k+1,k) - R(k,k) ≥ 2k-5.

title: Erdős Problem #1031: Induced Regular Subgraphs in Non-Ramsey Graphs
description: If G on n vertices has no trivial subgraph on ≥ 10 log n vertices, must G contain an induced non-trivial regular subgraph on ≫ log n vertices? YES (Prömel-Rödl 1999). Stronger: such G is c log n - universal.

title: Erdős Problem #1033: Triangle Degree Sums in Dense Graphs
description: Let h(n) = max k such that every graph on n vertices with > n²/4 edges contains a triangle with degree sum ≥ k. Conjecture: h(n) ≥ (2(√3−1)−o(1))n ≈ 1.464n. Known: (21/16)n ≤ h(n) ≤ 2(√3−1)n.

title: Erdős Problem #1034: Triangle Neighbors in Dense Graphs
description: Let G have n vertices and > n²/4 edges. Must there exist a triangle T with > (1/2 - o(1))n vertices each adjacent to ≥ 2 of T's vertices? NO (Ma-Tang). Bounds: (1/6)n ≤ h(n) ≤ (2 - √(5/2))n ≈ 0.419n.

title: Erdős Problem #1036: Distinct Induced Subgraphs in Non-Ramsey Graphs
description: Let G be non-Ramsey (no trivial subgraph on > c log n vertices). Must G contain ≥ 2^{Ω_c(n)} non-isomorphic induced subgraphs? YES (Shelah 1998). Prior: Alon-Hajnal (1991) proved exp(n(log n)^{-O(log log n)}).

title: Erdős Problem #1037: Degree Diversity and Ramsey Properties
description: Let G have n vertices where every degree occurs at most twice and distinct degrees > (1/2 + ε)n. Must G have a trivial subgraph much larger than log n? NO (Cambie-Chan-Hunter). Counterexample: ≥ 3n/4 distinct degrees, max trivial O(log n).

title: Erdős Problem #1038: Sublevel Sets of Monic Polynomials
description: Determine the infimum and supremum of the measure of {x : |f(x)| < 1} for monic polynomials with roots in [-1,1]. Supremum = 2√2 (Tao, 2025); infimum bounds: 1.519 ≤ inf ≤ 1.835.

title: Erdős Problem #1039: Polynomial Lemniscate Disc Radius
description: Let f(z) = ∏(z-zᵢ) with |zᵢ| ≤ 1. Let ρ(f) = radius of largest disc in {z: |f(z)| < 1}. Is ρ(f) ≫ 1/n? OPEN. Known: 1/(2en²) ≤ ρ(f) (Pommerenke), ρ(f) ≫ 1/(n√log n) (KLR 2025). Upper: ρ(zⁿ-1) ≤ π/(2n).

title: Erdős Problem #104: Unit Circles Through Three Points
description: Given n points in ℝ², how many unit circles contain at least 3 points? Known: Ω(n^{3/2}) ≤ answer ≤ O(n²). Conjecture: O(n^{3/2}). OPEN ($100 prize).

title: Erdős Problem #1040: Transfinite Diameter and Sublevel Set Measure
description: Let F ⊆ ℂ be closed infinite, μ(F) = inf of |{z: |f(z)| < 1}| over polynomials with roots in F. Is μ(F) determined by transfinite diameter? Is μ(F) = 0 when ρ(F) ≥ 1? OPEN. Known for line segments/discs (EHP 1958).

title: Erdős Problem #1041: Paths in Polynomial Level Sets
description: For a monic polynomial with all roots in the unit disk, must there exist a path of length less than 2 in the sublevel set {z : |f(z)| < 1} connecting two roots?

title: Erdős Problem #1042: Connected Components of Polynomial Lemniscates
description: For polynomials with roots in a closed set F ⊆ ℂ, how many connected components can the lemniscate {z : |f(z)| < 1} have? The answer depends on the transfinite diameter of F and its geometry. Solved by Ghosh-Ramachandran (2024).

title: Erdős #1043: Polynomial Level Set Projections
description: For a monic polynomial f, must some line's projection of {z : |f(z)| ≤ 1} have measure ≤ 2? NO (Pommerenke 1961): can be ≥ 2.386, but always ≤ 3.3.

title: Erdős Problem #1044: Boundary Length of Polynomial Level Sets
description: For polynomials f(z) with all roots in the unit disk, what is the infimum of the maximum boundary length of connected components of {z : |f(z)| < 1}? Tang proved the answer is 2, achieved in the limit but not by any specific polynomial.

title: Erdős Problem #1045: Maximum Product of Distances
description: Given n complex points with pairwise distances ≤ 2, maximize ∏|zᵢ-zⱼ|. Regular polygon is NOT optimal for even n ≥ 4. Odd n case remains open.

title: Lemniscate Containment in a Disc
description: For monic f ∈ ℂ[x], if E = {z : |f(z)| < 1} is connected, is E in a disc of radius 2? YES (Pommerenke 1959). The center is the root centroid. But the width conjecture is FALSE.

title: Erdős Problem #1047: Convexity of Polynomial Lemniscates
description: Must the connected components of {z : |f(z)| ≤ c} be convex for small c? No! Grunsky's conjecture was disproved by Pommerenke (1961) and Goodman (1966) with explicit counterexamples.

title: Erdős Problem #1048: Polynomial Lemniscate Diameter
description: For a monic polynomial f ∈ ℂ[x] with roots in |z| ≤ r where r < 2, must L(f,1) = {z : |f(z)| < 1} have a component with diameter > 2-r? DISPROVED by Pommerenke (1961) for r > 1.

title: Erdős Problem #1049: Irrationality of Divisor Sums
description: For rational t > 1, is ∑_{n≥1} 1/(t^n - 1) = ∑_{n≥1} τ(n)/t^n irrational? OPEN: Erdős proved YES for integer t ≥ 2. Chowla's conjecture for all rationals unresolved.

title: Erdős Problem #105: Lines Avoiding a Point Set
description: Given n points A (not collinear) and n-3 points B, must some line hit 2+ points of A and miss B entirely? DISPROVED by Xichuan with explicit counterexamples. Variants with n-4 or (1-o(1))n remain open.

title: Erdős Problem #1050: Irrationality of ∑ 1/(2^n - 3)
description: Is ∑_{n≥1} 1/(2^n - 3) irrational? SOLVED by Borwein (1991): YES. More generally, ∑ 1/(q^n + r) is irrational for q ≥ 2 and rational r ≠ 0, r ≠ -q^n.

title: Erdős #1052: Unitary Perfect Numbers
description: A unitary perfect number equals the sum of its proper unitary divisors (where d is unitary if gcd(d, n/d)=1). All unitary perfect numbers are even; finiteness is OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1054: Sum of Smallest Divisors
description: Let f(n) be the minimal integer m such that n equals the sum of the k smallest divisors of m for some k ≥ 1. Is f(n) = o(n)? Or is this true only for almost all n, with limsup f(n)/n = ∞?

title: Erdős Problem #1057: Counting Carmichael Numbers
description: Let C(x) count Carmichael numbers in [1,x]. Is C(x) = x^{1-o(1)}? Known: x^{0.3389} < C(x) < x·exp(-c·log x·log log log x / log log x). OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1058: Prime Divisors of n!+1 Between Consecutive Primes
description: Are there only finitely many n in [p_{k-1}, p_k) such that the only primes dividing n!+1 are p_k and p_{k+1}? SOLVED: Luca (2001) proved the only solutions are n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

title: Erdős Problem #106: Square Packing in the Unit Square
description: Pack n squares in the unit square with disjoint interiors. Let f(n) = max sum of side lengths. Is f(k²+1) = k? Known: f(k²) = k, f(2) = 1, f(5) = 2. Axis-parallel case solved (2024). OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1060: Counting Solutions to k·σ(k) = n
description: Let f(n) count solutions to k·σ(k) = n. Is f(n) ≤ n^{o(1/log log n)}? Perhaps even f(n) ≤ (log n)^{O(1)}? This problem remains OPEN.

title: Erdos Problem #1061: Additive Divisor Equation
description: How many ordered pairs (a,b) satisfy sigma(a)+sigma(b)=sigma(a+b) with a+b<=x? Is this count asymptotic to cx for some c>0?

title: Erdős Problem #1064: Comparing φ(n) and φ(n - φ(n))
description: Is φ(n) > φ(n - φ(n)) for almost all n? Yes (density 1), but the reverse holds infinitely often. Solved by Luca-Pomerance and Grytczuk-Luca-Wójtowicz.

title: Erdős Problem #1066: Independence Number of Unit Distance Graphs
description: Let G be a graph given by n points in ℝ² where any two distinct points are at least distance 1 apart, and we draw an edge between two points if they are distance exactly 1 apart. Let g(n) be maximal such that any such graph always has an independent set on at least g(n) vertices. Estimate g(n), or perhaps lim g(n)/n.

title: Erdős Problem #1067: Infinitely Connected Subgraphs with Chromatic Number ℵ₁
description: Does every graph with χ = ℵ₁ contain an infinitely connected subgraph with χ = ℵ₁? DISPROVED by Soukup (2015), Bowler-Pitz (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #1069: Szemerédi-Trotter Theorem on k-Rich Lines
description: Given n points in ℝ², the number of k-rich lines (containing ≥k points) is O(n²/k³) for k ≤ √n. Proved by Szemerédi-Trotter (1983).

title: Erdős Problem #107: The Happy Ending Problem
description: Let f(n) be minimal such that any f(n) points in ℝ², no three collinear, contain n points forming a convex n-gon. The conjecture f(n) = 2^{n-2} + 1 remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1070: Independence Number of Unit Distance Graphs
description: Estimate f(n), the minimum independence number of n-point unit distance graphs in ℝ². Is f(n) ≥ n/4? Best bounds: 0.22936n ≤ f(n) ≤ (2/7)n. The n/4 question cannot be resolved via density methods.

title: Erdős Problem #1074: EHS Numbers and Pillai Primes
description: Do the asymptotic densities of EHS numbers and Pillai primes exist? Both sets are infinite (Erdős-Hardy-Subbarao), but density questions remain OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1075: Dense Subgraphs in r-Uniform Hypergraphs
description: For r ≥ 3, does there exist c_r > r^{-r} such that any r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices with ≥ (1+ε)(n/r)^r edges contains an m-vertex subgraph with ≥ c_r·m^r edges? Erdős proved c_r = r^{-r} works with threshold εn^r. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1076: Extremal Numbers for 3-Uniform Hypergraphs
description: For k ≥ 5, let F_k be all 3-uniform hypergraphs with k vertices and k-2 edges. Is ex₃(n, F_k) ~ n²/6? SOLVED: YES (Bohman-Warnke 2019, Glock-Kühn-Lo-Osthus 2020).

title: Erdős Problem #1077: Balanced Subgraphs in Dense Graphs
description: Must dense graphs contain large balanced subgraphs? Jiang-Longbrake (2025) showed the optimal size is Θ(n^α) vertices, resolving ambiguities in the original problem.

title: Erdős Problem #1078: Minimum Degree for K_r in r-Partite Graphs
description: In r-partite graphs with n vertices per part, min degree ≥ (r-3/2-o(1))n implies K_r exists. SOLVED by Haxell (2001). Sharp threshold by Haxell-Szabó (2006).

title: Erdős Problem #1079: Turán Density in Neighborhoods
description: For r ≥ 4, if G has n vertices and ≥ ex(n; Kᵣ) edges, must G contain a vertex with dense neighborhood? SOLVED: YES (Bollobás-Thomason 1981, Bondy 1983). A nice generalization of Turán's theorem.

title: Erdős Problem #108: High Chromatic Subgraphs with Large Girth
description: For every r >= 4 and k >= 2, does there exist f(k,r) such that every graph with chromatic number >= f(k,r) contains a subgraph of girth >= r and chromatic number >= k?

title: Erdős Problem #1080: Six-Cycles in Sparse Bipartite Graphs
description: Is there a constant c > 0 such that bipartite graphs with n vertices (one part of size ⌊n^(2/3)⌋) and cn edges must contain a C_6? NO, disproved by De Caen-Székely (1992).

title: Erdős Problem #1081: Sums of Two Squarefull Numbers
description: Let A(x) count integers n ≤ x that are sums of two squarefull numbers. Is A(x) ~ c·x/√(log x)? NO, disproved by Odoni (1981). Correct asymptotic: A(x) ~ x/(log x)^α where α = 1-2^(-1/3) ≈ 0.206.

title: Erdős Problem #1082: Distinct Distances in General Position
description: Let A ⊂ ℝ² be n points with no three collinear. Does A determine ≥ n/2 distinct distances? The stronger form (single point with n/2 distances) was disproved by Xichuan.

title: Erdős Problem #1083: Distinct Distances in Higher Dimensions
description: Let d ≥ 3, and let f_d(n) be the minimal m such that every n-point set in ℝ^d determines at least m distinct distances. Is f_d(n) = n^{2/d - o(1)}?

title: Erdős Problem #1085: The Unit Distance Problem
description: Let f_d(n) be the maximum number of pairs at unit distance among n points in ℝ^d. For d=2: n^(1+o(1)) ≤ f_2(n) ≤ O(n^(4/3)) with gap OPEN. For d≥4: f_d(n) ≈ (p-1)/(2p)·n² where p=⌊d/2⌋ (essentially SOLVED).

title: Erdős Problem #1086: Triangles of Equal Area
description: Let g(n) be the maximum number of triangles with the same area determined by n points in ℝ². Best bounds: n² log log n ≪ g(n) ≪ n^{20/9}. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdos Problem #1087: Degenerate Quadruples in Point Sets
description: Estimate f(n), the maximum number of degenerate 4-point sets in n points in the plane. Is f(n) at most n^{3+o(1)}?

title: Erdos Problem #1088: Distinct Distance Subsets in High Dimensions
description: Let f_d(n) be the minimal m such that any m points in R^d contain n points with all pairwise distances distinct. Is f_d(n) = 2^{o(d)} for fixed n >= 3? OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1089: Distinct Distances in Higher Dimensions
description: Let g_d(n) be minimal such that every g_d(n) points in ℝ^d determine at least n distinct distances. Does lim_{d→∞} g_d(n)/d^{n-1} exist? Known: g_d(n) ≫ d^{n-1}, but g_d(n) ≤ c^{d^{1-b_n}}. OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #109: The Sumset Conjecture
description: Any subset A of natural numbers with positive upper density contains a sumset B + C where both B and C are infinite.

title: Erdős Problem #1090: Monochromatic Collinear Points
description: For k ≥ 3, does there exist a finite set A ⊂ ℝ² such that any 2-coloring has k monochromatic collinear points? SOLVED: YES. Graham-Selfridge proved k=3; Hunter used Hales-Jewett for general k.

title: Erdős Problem #1091: Odd Cycles with Diagonals in K₄-Free Graphs
description: Must a K₄-free graph with χ(G) = 4 contain an odd cycle with at least two diagonals? Answer: YES (Voss 1982). General f(r) question: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1095: The Erdős-Selfridge Function
description: Let g(k) be the smallest n > k+1 such that all prime factors of C(n,k) exceed k. Estimate g(k). Known: exp(c·(log k)²) ≪ g(k) ≤ exp((1+o(1))k). Conjectured: log g(k) ~ k/log k. OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1096: Gap Convergence in q-Expansions
description: For 1 < q < 1 + ε, do gaps in the sequence of q-representable numbers tend to 0? Conjectured threshold: smallest Pisot number q₀ ≈ 1.3247.

title: Non-Commuting Graphs of Groups
description: If the non-commuting graph Γ(G) has no infinite clique, is there a finite bound on clique sizes? YES (Neumann 1976). Equivalent to Z(G) having finite index.

title: Erdős Problem #1099: Divisor Ratio Sum Boundedness
description: For α > 1, is liminf h_α(n) bounded, where h_α(n) = Σ((d_{i+1}/dᵢ) - 1)^α over consecutive divisors? YES, proved by Vose (1984).

title: Erdős Problem #11: Squarefree + Power of 2
description: Is every odd n > 1 the sum of a squarefree number and a power of 2? OPEN problem with deep connections to Wieferich primes. Verified up to 2^50.

title: Erdős Problem #110: Chromatic Number Growth in Uncountable Graphs
description: Is there F(n) such that every ℵ₁-chromatic graph has an n-chromatic subgraph on ≤F(n) vertices? DISPROVED by Lambie-Hanson (2020) in ZFC. Earlier, Shelah showed consistency of a negative answer.

title: Erdős Problem #1100: Coprime Consecutive Divisors
description: Let 1 = d₁ < d₂ < ... < d_τ(n) = n be the divisors of n. Define τ⊥(n) as the count of indices i where gcd(dᵢ, dᵢ₊₁) = 1. Three questions: (1) Does τ⊥(n)/ω(n) → ∞ for almost all n? (2) Is τ⊥(n) < exp((log n)^o(1)) for all n? (3) For squarefree n with ω(n) = k, what is g(k) = max τ⊥(n)?

title: Erdős Problem #1101: Good Sequences and Gaps in Sieved Integers
description: Given a pairwise coprime sequence u with convergent reciprocal series, when do the integers not divisible by any uᵢ have gaps bounded by the product formula?

title: Erdős Problem #1102: Squarefree Properties P and Q
description: How fast must sequences with squarefree properties P or Q grow? van Doorn-Tao (2025) resolved this: P-sequences have density 0, Q-sequences have upper density at most 6/π².

title: Erdős Problem #1105: Anti-Ramsey Numbers for Cycles and Paths
description: Determine exact formulas for the anti-Ramsey numbers AR(n, C_k) and AR(n, P_k), where AR(n,G) is the maximum number of colors in a rainbow-G-free edge-coloring of K_n.

title: Erdős #1106: Prime Factors of Partition Products
description: Let F(n) count distinct prime factors of ∏_{k=1}^n p(k) where p(k) is the partition function. Does F(n) → ∞? Is F(n) > n eventually? The first is proved; the second remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #1107: Sums of r-Powerful Numbers
description: Is every sufficiently large integer expressible as the sum of at most r+1 many r-powerful numbers?

title: Erdős Problem #1108: Factorial Sums and Perfect Powers
description: Does the set of finite sums of distinct factorials contain only finitely many k-th powers (for k >= 2)? Does it contain only finitely many powerful numbers?

title: Erdős Problem #1109: Squarefree Sumsets
description: Let f(N) be the max size of A ⊆ {1,...,N} with A+A squarefree. Is f(N) ≤ N^{o(1)} or (log N)^{O(1)}? Current bounds: (log log N)(log N)² ≪ f(N) ≪ N^{11/15+o(1)}. OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #111: Edge Deletion to Bipartiteness for Large Chromatic Graphs
description: For graphs with chromatic number ℵ₁, does the ratio h_G(n)/n tend to infinity, where h_G(n) measures edges needed to make n-vertex subgraphs bipartite?

title: Erdős Problem #1110: Representability by Sums of p^k q^l
description: For coprime p > q ≥ 2, when can integers be represented as sums of p^k q^l where no term divides another? The {2,3} case has all positive integers representable; other cases have infinitely many exceptions.

title: Erdős Problem #1111: Anticomplete High-Chromatic Subgraphs
description: For t, c ≥ 1, find d(t, c): minimal d such that any graph with χ(G) ≥ d and ω(G) < t has anticomplete sets A, B with χ(A) ≥ χ(B) ≥ c. Known: d(2,2)=2, d(3,2)=4, d(4,2)=5. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1112: k-fold Sumsets Avoiding Lacunary Sequences
description: For k ≥ 3 and gap bounds d₁ < d₂, does there exist r such that for any r-lacunary sequence B, there exists A with bounded gaps where the k-fold sumset kA avoids B?

title: Erdős Problem #1113: Sierpinski Numbers Without Covering Sets
description: Are there Sierpinski numbers with no finite covering set? OPEN. Izotov's candidate m = 734110615000775^4 is conjectured uncovered. If NO, infinitely many Fermat primes would exist.

title: Erdős Problem #1114: Monotonicity of Critical Point Gaps
description: For a polynomial f with real roots in arithmetic progression, the gaps between consecutive critical points of f' increase outward from the midpoint.

title: Erdős Problem #1115: Path Length for Entire Functions
description: For finite-order entire functions f(z), can we find a path Γ to infinity with ℓ(r) ≪ r? DISPROVED by Gol'dberg-Eremenko (1979). Hayman showed YES if log M(r) ≪ (log r)², but counterexamples exist for any faster growth.

title: Erdős Problem #1116: Extreme Value Distribution of Entire Functions
description: Does there exist an entire function f such that for every a ≠ b, lim sup n(r,a)/n(r,b) = ∞? YES - proved by Gol'dberg (1978) and Toppila (1976) who constructed such functions.

title: Erdős Problem #1118: Entire Functions with Finite Measure Superlevel Sets
description: For entire f with |{z:|f(z)|>c}| finite: (1) What is minimum growth? (2) Must smaller c' work? SOLVED: Camera-Gol'dberg 1977-79.

title: Erdős Problem #1119: Families of Entire Functions with Cardinal Constraints
description: If a family of entire functions has at most 𝔪 distinct values at each point, must the family have cardinality ≤ 𝔪? Answer: YES if 𝔪⁺ < 𝔠, UNDECIDABLE if 𝔪⁺ = 𝔠.

title: Circle Covering Theorem
description: If circles C₁,...,Cₙ with radii r₁,...,rₙ have no separating line, they can be covered by a circle of radius Σrᵢ. Proved by Goodman-Goodman (1945), generalizes to higher dimensions.

title: Erdős Problem #1122: Additive Functions and Monotonicity Defects
description: Let f: ℕ → ℝ be additive. If the set A = {n : f(n+1) < f(n)} has |A ∩ [1,X]| = o(X), must f(n) = c·log(n)?

title: Erdős Problem #1123: Boolean Algebras Modulo Density Zero Sets
description: Are B₁ = P(ℕ)/I₁ and B₂ = P(ℕ)/I₂ isomorphic, where I₁, I₂ are the density-zero and log-density-zero ideals? Set-theoretically dependent: YES under CH (Just-Krawczyk 1984).

title: Erdős Problem #1124: Tarski's Circle-Squaring Problem
description: Can a circle and square of equal area be decomposed into finitely many congruent pieces? SOLVED by Laczkovich (1990): YES, using translations only with approximately 10^50 pieces.

title: Erdős Problem #1125: Kemperman's Inequality and Monotonicity
description: If f : ℝ → ℝ satisfies 2f(x) ≤ f(x+h) + f(x+2h) for all x and h > 0, must f be monotonic? Laczkovich (1984) proved YES unconditionally.

title: Erdős Problem #1126: Almost Additive Functions
description: If f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y) for almost all x,y ∈ ℝ, then there exists g with g(x+y) = g(x) + g(y) for ALL x,y and f = g a.e. Proved by de Bruijn (1966) and Jurkat (1965).

title: Decomposing ℝⁿ into Sets with Distinct Distances
description: Can ℝⁿ be decomposed into countably many sets where all pairwise distances within each set are distinct? YES assuming the Continuum Hypothesis (Erdős-Kakutani 1943 for n=1, Davies 1972 for n=2, Kunen 1987 for all n). CH is necessary.

title: Erdős Problem #1128: Monochromatic Cubes in Cardinal Products
description: Let A, B, C have cardinality ℵ₁. Must any 2-coloring of A × B × C contain a countably infinite monochromatic cube A₁ × B₁ × C₁? DISPROVED by Prikry-Mills (1978): NO, such colorings exist with no ℵ₀ × ℵ₀ × ℵ₀ monochromatic cube.

title: Erdős Problem #1129: Optimal Lagrange Interpolation Nodes
description: Which choice of interpolation nodes x₁,...,xₙ in [-1,1] minimizes the Lebesgue constant Λ = max Σ|l_k(x)|? SOLVED: Optimal nodes exist, are characterized by equal subinterval maxima, and achieve Λ ~ (2/π) log n.

title: Erdős Problem #113: Extremal Numbers and Degeneracy of Bipartite Graphs
description: The Erdős-Simonovits Conjecture (1984) claimed: for bipartite G, ex(n;G) ≪ n^{3/2} if and only if G is 2-degenerate. DISPROVED by Janzer (2023) who constructed 3-regular bipartite H with ex(n;H) ≪ n^{4/3+ε}.

title: Minimizing Lagrange Interpolation Basis Polynomial Integrals
description: For points x₁,...,xₙ ∈ [-1,1], what is the minimum of ∫ Σ |l_k(x)|² dx over all Lagrange basis configurations? Conjecture: min I = 2 - (1+o(1))/n. OPEN problem.

title: Erdős Problem #1132: Lagrange Interpolation and Lebesgue Functions
description: Two open questions about Lebesgue functions Lₙ(x) for infinite node sequences: must there exist x with large Lₙ(x) infinitely often, and is the growth property satisfied almost everywhere?

title: Erdos Problem #1133: Large Polynomial Interpolation Bound
description: For any C > 0, can one always choose target values y_i in [-1,1] for sample points x_i such that any low-degree polynomial approximating most points must exceed C somewhere in [-1,1]? OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #1134: Density of Sets Closed Under Affine Maps
description: Let A ⊆ ℕ be the smallest set containing 1 and closed under x ↦ 2x+1, x ↦ 3x+1, and x ↦ 6x+1. Does A have positive lower density? Answer: NO.

title: Erdős Problem #12: Divisibility-Free Sets
description: How large can a set A be if no element a divides the sum b+c of two larger elements? Three OPEN questions about density, sparseness, and reciprocal sums.

title: Erdős Problem #120: The Similarity Problem
description: For every infinite A ⊆ ℝ, must there exist a set E of positive measure containing no similar copy of A?

title: Erdős Problem #121: Square-Free Products
description: Let F_k(N) be the max size of A ⊆ {1,…,N} with no k-element product a perfect square. Conjecture F_{2k+1}(N) = (1-o(1))N. DISPROVED by Tao (2024): F_k(N) ≤ (1-c_k)N for k ≥ 4.

title: Erdős #123: d-Complete Sequences
description: Is the set {a^i·b^j·c^k : i,j,k ≥ 0} d-complete for pairwise coprime a,b,c? OPEN in general; {2^k·3^l} case is SOLVED.

title: Erdos Problem #124: Complete Sequences
description: The first open mathematical conjecture solved autonomously by AI: every natural number is representable using 0/1 digits across multiple bases when the reciprocal condition is met.

title: Erdős Problem #13: Divisibility-Free Sets
description: For A ⊆ {1,...,N} with no a,b,c where a|(b+c) and a < min(b,c), is |A| ≤ N/3 + O(1)? SOLVED by Bedert (2023). The upper third (2N/3, N] is optimal.

title: Non-Dividing Sets
description: Maximum size of A ⊆ {1,...,N} where no a ∈ A divides the sum of other elements. Original question resolved (NO), but exact growth rate remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #132: Distance Multiplicities in Planar Point Sets
description: Given n points in ℝ², must there exist two distances that each occur at most n times? True for n=5,6 (Erdős-Fishburn 1995) and convex position (CDL 2025), but OPEN for general n≥7.

title: Erdős Problem #133: Maximum Degree in Triangle-Free Diameter-2 Graphs
description: Let f(n) be minimal such that every triangle-free graph G with n vertices and diameter 2 contains a vertex with degree ≥ f(n). Does f(n)/√n → ∞? Answer: NO, f(n) = Θ(√n).

title: Erdős Problem #134: Triangle-Free Graphs with Diameter 2
description: Can a triangle-free graph G on n vertices with max degree < n^{1/2-ε} be extended to a triangle-free diameter-2 graph by adding at most δn² edges? SOLVED: YES (Alon proved O(n^{2-ε}) edges suffice).

title: Erdős Problem #135: Four Points, Five Distances
description: If any 4 points from A ⊂ ℝ² determine at least 5 distinct distances, must A determine ≫ n² distances? DISPROVED by Tao (2024).

title: The Erdős-Gyárfás Function f(n,4,5)
description: Minimum colors to edge-color Kₙ so every K₄ has ≥5 colors among its 6 edges. Answer: f(n) ~ (5/6)n. Erdős-Gyárfás bounds: (5/6)(n-1) < f(n) < n. Resolved by Bennett et al. (2022).

title: Erdős Problem #137: Powerful Products of Consecutive Integers
description: For k ≥ 3, can the product of k consecutive integers ever be powerful? Conjectured: NO.

title: Van der Waerden Numbers Growth Rate
description: Erdős Problem #138 asks whether W(k)^{1/k} → ∞, where W(k) is the van der Waerden number - the minimum N such that any 2-coloring of {1,...,N} contains a monochromatic k-term arithmetic progression. This remains OPEN with a $500 prize.

title: Erdős #139: Szemerédi's Theorem
description: Szemerédi's theorem states that any subset of natural numbers with positive upper density contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. This formalization covers the equivalent density formulation: r_k(N) = o(N), where r_k(N) is the maximum size of a k-AP-free subset of {1,...,N}.

title: Erdős Problem #140: Density of 3-AP-Free Sets
description: Let r₃(N) be the size of the largest subset of {1,...,N} with no 3-term arithmetic progression. Prove r₃(N) ≪ N/(log N)^C for every C > 0. SOLVED by Kelley-Meka (2023).

title: Erdős Problem #141: Consecutive Primes in Arithmetic Progression
description: Are there k consecutive primes in arithmetic progression for every k >= 3?

title: Erdős Problem #143: Sparseness of Dilation-Avoiding Sets
description: If A ⊂ (1,∞) satisfies |kx - y| ≥ 1 for all distinct x,y ∈ A and k ≥ 1, must A be sparse?

title: Erdős Problem #144: Propinquity of Divisors
description: The density of integers with two divisors d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁ exists and equals 1. SOLVED by Maier-Tenenbaum (1984), who proved the stronger version for any c > 1. The threshold β* = log 3 - 1 separates density 1 from density 0.

title: Erdős Problem #145: Moments of Squarefree Gaps
description: Let s₁ < s₂ < ... be the sequence of squarefree numbers. Does the limit of (1/x) ∑_{sₙ≤x} (s_{n+1} - sₙ)^α exist for all α ≥ 0?

title: Erdős Problem #146: Turán Numbers for Bipartite r-Degenerate Graphs
description: If H is bipartite and r-degenerate, is ex(n;H) ≪ n^{2-1/r}? OPEN even for r=2. Best known: n^{2-1/4r} (AKS 2003). Prize: $500.

title: Erdős Problem #147: Turán Numbers for Bipartite Graphs
description: If H is bipartite with minimum degree r, is ex(n;H) ≫ n^{2-1/(r-1)+ε}? NO, disproved by Janzer (2023) who showed ex(n;H) ≪ n^{2-2/r+ε}.

title: Erdos Problem #148: Unit Fraction Decompositions
description: Find good estimates for F(k), the count of ways to write 1 as a sum of k distinct unit fractions. Known bounds: 2^{c*k/log k} <= F(k) <= c_0^{(1/5+o(1))*2^k}.

title: Erdős Problem #149: Strong Chromatic Index Conjecture
description: Is χ'_s(G) ≤ (5/4)Δ² for all graphs G with maximum degree Δ? This asks if every graph can be strongly edge-colored using at most (5/4)Δ² colors. OPEN - best bound is 1.772Δ² (Hurley-de Joannis de Verclos-Kang 2022).

title: Erdős Problem #15: Alternating Prime Series
description: Does the alternating series Σ(-1)^n · n/p_n converge? OPEN problem, conditionally proved by Tao (2023) assuming Hardy-Littlewood.

title: Erdos Problem #150: Minimal Cuts in Graphs
description: Does the maximum number of minimal vertex cuts in an n-vertex graph satisfy c(n)^{1/n} converging to some alpha < 2? YES, proved by Bradac (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #154: Distribution of Sidon Sumsets over Moduli
description: For Sidon sets A ⊂ {1,...,N} with |A| ~ √N, must A+A be well-distributed over all small moduli? SOLVED: YES (Lindström 1998, Kolountzakis 1999).

title: Erdős Problem #156: Minimum Size of Maximal Sidon Sets
description: Does there exist a maximal Sidon set A ⊂ {1,...,N} of size O(N^{1/3})?

title: Erdős Problem #157: Infinite Sidon Set as Asymptotic Basis
description: Does there exist an infinite Sidon set which is an asymptotic basis of order 3? YES (Pilatte 2023). Two theorems verified: sidon_iff_sidon_alt and powers_of_two_sidon.

title: Erdős Problem #158: B₂[g] Sets and Counting Function Growth
description: For an infinite B₂[2] set A (at most 2 representations per sum), must liminf |A ∩ {1,...,N}|/√N = 0?

title: Erdős Problem #16: Odd Integers Not of Form 2^k + p
description: Is the set of odd integers not of the form 2^k + p the union of an arithmetic progression and a density-0 set? DISPROVED by Chen (2023).

title: Erdős Problem #161: Almost Monochromatic Subsets in Hypergraph Colorings
description: Does F^(t)(n,α) have jumps as α varies from 0 to 1/2? SOLVED for t=3 by Conlon-Fox-Sudakov (2011): exactly one jump at α=0. F^(t)(n,α) measures the largest m ensuring every large subset has balanced colors.

title: Erdős Problem #163: The Burr-Erdős Conjecture
description: For d-degenerate graph H on n vertices, is R(H) = O(n)? SOLVED: YES, R(H) ≤ 2^{2^{O(d)}} · n (Lee, 2017).

title: Erdős Problem #164
description:

A set ... is primitive if no member of ... divides another. Is the sum\[\sum_{n\in A}{n\log n}\]maximised over all primitive ...

title: Erdős Problem #165: Asymptotic Formula for R(3,k)
description: Determine the asymptotic formula for R(3,k), the Ramsey number for triangles vs independent sets. The answer is R(3,k) = Θ(k²/log k), with current best bounds (1/2 - o(1))k²/log k ≤ R(3,k) ≤ (1 + o(1))k²/log k.

title: Erdős Problem #166: Ramsey Number R(4,k) Lower Bound
description: Prove that R(4,k) >> k³/(log k)^O(1). SOLVED by Mattheus-Verstraete (2023): R(4,k) >> k³/(log k)⁴, earning the $250 Erdős prize.

title: Erdős Problem #167: Tuza's Conjecture
description: If G is a graph with at most k edge-disjoint triangles, can G be made triangle-free by removing at most 2k edges? Tuza's Conjecture (1981) remains open in general.

title: Erdős Problem #168: {n, 2n, 3n}-Free Sets
description: Let F(N) be the maximum size of a subset of {1,...,N} avoiding {n, 2n, 3n} triples. What is lim F(N)/N? Is it irrational?

title: Erdős Problem #169: Harmonic Sum of AP-Free Sets
description: For k ≥ 3, estimate f(k), the supremum of ∑ 1/n over sets lacking k-term arithmetic progressions. Is lim f(k)/log W(k) = ∞?

title: Erdős Problem #17: Cluster Primes
description: Are there infinitely many cluster primes? A prime p is a cluster prime if every even n ≤ p-3 can be expressed as a difference of primes ≤ p. First non-cluster prime: 97.

title: Erdős Problem #170: Sparse Rulers (Perfect Difference Bases)
description: Let F(N) be the minimum size of A ⊆ {0,...,N} such that every k ∈ {1,...,N} is a difference of elements in A. Find lim F(N)/√N.

title: Erdős Problem #171: Unit Distance Chromatic Number
description: What is the chromatic number χ(ℝ²) of the unit distance graph? The Hadwiger-Nelson problem. Nelson (1950): χ ≥ 4. Isbell (1950): χ ≤ 7. de Grey (2018): χ ≥ 5. Current knowledge: 5 ≤ χ(ℝ²) ≤ 7.

title: Erdős Problem #172: Monochromatic Sums and Products
description: In any finite coloring of ℕ, do there exist arbitrarily large sets A with all sums and products of elements monochromatic?

title: Erdos Problem #173: Monochromatic Triangles in Plane Colorings
description: In any 2-coloring of R^2, all but at most one triangle T has a monochromatic congruent copy. Shader proved this for all right triangles. The equilateral triangle is the candidate exception.

title: Erdős Problem #174: Euclidean Ramsey Sets
description: Characterize which finite sets in ℝⁿ are Ramsey: guaranteed to contain monochromatic copies under any k-coloring of high-dimensional space. Known: Ramsey implies spherical. OPEN: Is every spherical set Ramsey?

title: Erdős Problem #175: Central Binomial Coefficient Not Squarefree
description: Show that for n ≥ 5, C(2n,n) is not squarefree. Proved by Granville-Ramaré (1996). The function f(n) = max prime power exponent satisfies (log n)^{1/4} ≪ f(n) ≪ log n.

title: Erdős Problem #176: Discrepancy of Arithmetic Progressions
description: Find bounds for N(k,ℓ), the minimal N such that any ±1 coloring of {1,...,N} has a k-AP with discrepancy ≥ ℓ. Known: N(k,1) exactly; Open: N(k,2) ≤ C^k?

title: Erdős Problem #177: Discrepancy of Arithmetic Progressions
description: Find the smallest h(d) such that there exists f: ℕ → {-1,1} with max discrepancy ≤ h(d) over all APs with difference d. Known: d^{1/2} ≤ h(d) ≤ d^{8+ε}. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #178: Balancing Infinite Collections of Integer Sequences
description: Does there exist f : ℕ → {-1,1} such that the discrepancy over any d sequences is bounded independently of m? SOLVED (Beck 1981): YES, with bound O(d^(4+ε)) (Beck 2017).

title: Erdős Problem #179: Arithmetic Progression Supersaturation
description: For integers 1 ≤ k < ℓ, define F_k(N, ℓ) as the minimum number such that every set A ⊆ ℕ of size N containing at least F_k(N, ℓ) many k-term APs must contain an ℓ-term AP. Questions: Is F₃(N, 4) = o(N²)? Is lim log F₃(N, ℓ) / log N = 2 for all ℓ > 3? Answer: YES to both.

title: Erdős Problem #18: Practical Numbers
description: Is h(n!) < n^o(1), where h(m) is the minimum number of divisors of m needed to represent all integers k < m? A number m is practical if every k < m is a sum of distinct divisors of m. Prize: $250.

title: Erdős Problem #182: Maximum Edges Avoiding k-Regular Subgraphs
description: For k >= 3, what is the maximum number of edges a graph on n vertices can have if it contains no k-regular subgraph? Resolved by Janzer-Sudakov (2023): the answer is Θ(n log log n).

title: Erdős Problem #183: Multicolor Triangle Ramsey Numbers
description: Determine the limit of R(3;k)^{1/k} as k approaches infinity, where R(3;k) is the minimum n such that any k-coloring of the edges of K_n contains a monochromatic triangle.

title: Graph Decomposition into Cycles and Edges
description: The Erdős-Gallai Conjecture: Any graph on n vertices can be decomposed into O(n) edge-disjoint cycles and edges. OPEN. Best known: O(n log* n) by Bucić-Montgomery (2022). Lower bound: (1+c)n from K_{3,n-3}.

title: Erdős Problem #185: Cap Sets in {0,1,2}^n
description: Is f₃(n) = o(3^n) where f₃(n) is the max cap set in {0,1,2}^n? YES - Proved via density Hales-Jewett (Furstenberg-Katznelson 1991).

title: Erdos Problem #186: Non-Averaging Sets
description: What is the maximum size of a non-averaging subset of {1,...,N}? Answer: N^(1/4+o(1)), essentially resolved by Bosznay (1989) and Pham-Zakharov (2024).

title: Erdos Problem #188: Unit Distance Colorings and Arithmetic Progressions
description: Find the smallest k such that R^2 can be red/blue colored with no red unit distances and no k-term blue AP with distance 1.

title: Erdős Problem #189: Rectangles of Every Area in Colored Planes
description: If the plane is finitely colored, must some color class contain rectangle vertices of every area? Disproved by Kovač (2023) with a 25-coloring.

title: Erdős Problem #19: Erdős-Faber-Lovász Conjecture
description: If G is an edge-disjoint union of n copies of K_n, then χ(G) = n.

title: Erdős Problem #190: Canonical Ramsey Number for Arithmetic Progressions
description: Estimate H(k), the smallest N guaranteeing either a monochromatic or rainbow k-term arithmetic progression in every coloring of {1,...,N}.

title: Erdős Problem #191: Monochromatic Sets with Large 1/log Sum
description: For any C > 0, if n is large enough, any 2-coloring of edges of K({2,...,n}) contains monochromatic X with Σ(1/log x) ≥ C. SOLVED by Rödl (2003). Tight bound: Θ(log log log n) by Conlon-Fox-Sudakov.

title: Erdős Problem #192: Unit Vector Sequences and Abelian Squares
description: For which d must an infinite unit vector sequence in ℝᵈ contain a 3-term AP? Answer: d ≤ 3 yes, d ≥ 4 no (Keränen 1992).

title: Erdos Problem #194: Chaotic Orderings and Monotone Arithmetic Progressions
description: Must any ordering of R contain a monotone k-term arithmetic progression? NO - Chaotic orderings exist that avoid all such progressions, even for k=3.

title: Erdős Problem #195: Monotone Arithmetic Progressions in Permutations
description: What is the largest k such that in any permutation of ℤ there must exist a monotone k-term arithmetic progression x₁ < x₂ < ... < xₖ?

title: Erdős Problem #197: Partition of ℕ Avoiding Monotone 3-AP Permutations
description: Can ℕ be partitioned into two sets, each of which can be permuted to avoid monotone 3-term arithmetic progressions? This problem remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #198: Sidon Sets and Arithmetic Progressions
description: If A ⊆ ℕ is a Sidon set, must the complement of A contain an infinite arithmetic progression? Answer: NO.

title: Erdős Problem #199: Arithmetic Progressions in Set Complements
description: If A ⊂ ℝ contains no 3-term arithmetic progression, must ℝ \ A contain an infinite arithmetic progression? NO - disproved by Baumgartner (1975) using the axiom of choice.

title: Erdős Problem #2: Covering Systems
description: Can the smallest modulus of a covering system be arbitrarily large? SOLVED: NO (Hough 2015, Balister et al. 2022).

title: Erdős Problem #20: The Sunflower Conjecture
description: Is f(n,k) < c_k^n where f(n,k) is the minimum family size guaranteeing a k-sunflower? OPEN with $1,000 prize. Major progress by ALWZ (2020) and Rao (2020).

title: Erdős #202: Disjoint Covering Systems
description: How many disjoint congruence classes can have moduli bounded by N? Bounds involve L(N) = exp(√(log N · log log N)).

title: Erdos Problem #203: Covering Systems and Prime Avoidance
description: Is there an integer m >= 1 with (m, 6) = 1 such that none of 2^k * 3^l * m + 1 are prime, for any k, l >= 0?

title: Erdős Problem #204: Disjoint Covering Systems by Divisors
description: Are there n with a covering system using divisors of n that is 'as disjoint as possible'? NO - Adenwalla (2025) proved no such n exists, confirming the Erdős-Graham conjecture.

title: Erdős Problem #205: 2^k + m with Few Prime Factors
description: Can all large n be written as 2^k + m where Ω(m) < log log m? DISPROVED by Barreto-Leeham (2026).

title: Erdős Problem #206: Eventually Greedy Egyptian Fractions
description: Are the best underapproximations by Egyptian fractions eventually constructed greedily for almost all x? Disproved by Kovač (2024): the set of eventually greedy numbers has Lebesgue measure zero.

title: Erdős Problem #207: High-Girth Steiner Triple Systems
description: For g≥2 and large admissible n, do STS(n) with girth ≥g exist? YES (Kwan-Sah-Sawhney-Simkin 2022).

title: Erdős Problem #208: Gaps Between Squarefree Numbers
description: Let s₁ < s₂ < ... be the squarefree numbers. Is it true that for any ε > 0, the gap s_{n+1} - sₙ ≪ sₙ^ε?

title: Erdős Problem #209: Gallai Triangles in Line Arrangements
description: Must every line arrangement (d ≥ 4 lines, no parallels, no 4-concurrent) have a Gallai triangle? NO, disproved by Füredi-Palásti (1984) and Escudero (2016).

title: Erdős Problem #21: Covering Intersecting Families
description: Let f(n) be the minimum size of an intersecting family of n-sets that covers all (n-1)-sets. Is f(n) = O(n)? SOLVED by Kahn (1994): YES.

title: Erdős Problem #210: Ordinary Lines
description: Let f(n) be the minimum number of ordinary lines (lines through exactly 2 points) for any n points not all collinear. Does f(n) → ∞? SOLVED: f(n) ≥ n/2 for large even n (Green-Tao, 2013) - TIGHT.

title: Erdős Problem #211: Lines Formed by Points in the Plane
description: For n points with at most n-k collinear (1≤k<n), there are Ω(kn) lines through ≥2 points. SOLVED by Beck and Szemerédi-Trotter (1983).

title: Erdős Problem #212: Rational Distance Sets in the Plane
description: Is there a dense subset of ℝ² such that all pairwise distances are rational? Conjectured NO by Ulam.

title: Erdős Problem #213: Integer Distance Sets in General Position
description: For n ≥ 4, are there n points in ℝ², no three on a line and no four on a circle, with all pairwise distances integers?

title: Erdős Problem #214: Unit Distance Free Sets and Unit Squares
description: If S ⊂ ℝ² has no two points at distance 1 apart, must the complement contain four points forming a unit square? YES (Juhász, 1979). More generally, the complement contains a congruent copy of any 4-point set.

title: Erdős #215: The Steinhaus Lattice Point Problem
description: Does there exist S ⊆ ℝ² such that every congruent copy of S contains exactly one integer lattice point? Surprisingly YES, proved by Jackson-Mauldin (2002) using the Axiom of Choice.

title: Erdős Problem #216: Empty Convex Polygons
description: Let g(k) be the smallest integer such that any g(k) points in ℝ² contains an empty convex k-gon. Does g(k) exist? PARTIALLY SOLVED: g(k) exists iff k ≤ 6, with g(3)=3, g(4)=5, g(5)=10, g(6)=30 (Heule-Scheucher 2024). For k ≥ 7, Horton sets prove g(k) does not exist.

title: Erdős Problem #217: Point Configurations with Distance Multiplicities
description: For which n are there n points in R² in general position with n-1 distinct distances where the i-th distance appears exactly i times? OPEN. Known for n ≤ 8 (Pomerance, Palásti), conjectured impossible for large n.

title: Erdos Problem #218: Prime Gap Densities
description: Let d_n = p_{n+1} - p_n be the prime gap. Erdos conjectured that the sets where d_{n+1} >= d_n and d_{n+1} <= d_n each have density 1/2, and that infinitely many equal gaps d_n = d_{n+1} exist. OPEN. Terence Tao: 'looks difficult'.

title: Erdős Problem #219: Arbitrarily Long Arithmetic Progressions of Primes
description: Are there arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions of primes? Answer: YES (Green-Tao 2008).

title: Erdős Problem #22: Ramsey-Turán Numbers for K₄
description: Is rt(n; 4, εn) ≥ n²/8? Can K₄-free graphs have n²/8 edges with sublinear independence number?

title: Erdős Problem #220: Squared Gaps Between Reduced Residues
description: For reduced residues a₁ < ⋯ < a_{φ(n)} mod n, is ∑(a_{k+1}-a_k)² ≪ n²/φ(n)? Montgomery-Vaughan (1986) proved YES, with general bound for any power γ ≥ 1.

title: Erdős Problem #221: Additive Complements with Powers of 2
description: Is there a set A ⊆ ℕ with |A ∩ {1,...,N}| ≪ N/log N such that every large integer can be written as 2^k + a for some k ≥ 0 and a ∈ A? SOLVED: YES, by Ruzsa (1972) using an ingenious construction based on powers of 5.

title: Erdős Problem #222: Gaps Between Sums of Two Squares
description: Let n₁ < n₂ < ⋯ be the integers that are sums of two squares. What are the best bounds on consecutive gaps n_{k+1} - n_k? Erdős (1951) showed gaps can be Ω(log n / √(log log n)). Bambah-Chowla (1947) proved gaps are O(n^(1/4)).

title: Erdős Problem #223: Maximum Diameter Pairs (Vázsonyi's Conjecture)
description: How many pairs of points can realize the diameter in an n-point configuration? f₂(n)=n, f₃(n)=2n-2, and f_d(n)~cn² for d≥4. Fully solved by Hopf-Pannwitz (1934), Grünbaum/Heppes/Strasziewicz (1956-57), Erdős (1960), and Swanepoel (2009).

title: Erdős Problem #224: Obtuse Angles in Point Sets
description: Any 2^d + 1 points in ℝ^d contain three points forming an obtuse angle. SOLVED by Danzer-Grünbaum (1962). Hypercube is extremal.

title: L¹ Norm of Trigonometric Polynomials with Real Roots
description: If a trigonometric polynomial has all roots on the unit circle and supremum norm 1, then its L¹ norm is at most 4.

title: Erdős Problem #226: Entire Functions Preserving Rationality
description: Is there an entire non-linear function f such that x ∈ ℚ ↔ f(x) ∈ ℚ for all real x? SOLVED: YES by Barth-Schneider (1970) - transcendental entire functions with this property exist.

title: Erdős Problem #227: Maximum Term vs Maximum Modulus
description: For an entire function f = Σaₙzⁿ, if lim μ(r)/M(r) exists (where μ(r) = max|aₙrⁿ| and M(r) = max|f(z)| on |z|=r), must it be 0? DISPROVED: Clunie-Hayman showed the limit can be any λ ∈ [0, 1/2].

title: Erdős Problem #228: Flat Littlewood Polynomials
description: For all large n, does there exist a polynomial P of degree n with ±1 coefficients such that √n ≪ |P(z)| ≪ √n for all |z|=1? Answer: YES (BBMST 2019).

title: Erdős Problem #229: Zeros of Derivatives of Entire Functions
description: Given discrete sets (Sₙ) in ℂ, can we find a transcendental entire function whose derivatives vanish on each Sₙ? Answer: YES (Barth-Schneider 1972).

title: Erdős Problem #23: Triangle-Free Graphs and Bipartiteness
description: Can every triangle-free graph on 5n vertices be made bipartite by deleting at most n² edges?

title: Erdős Problem #230: Ultraflat Polynomials on the Unit Circle
description: For unimodular polynomials P(z) = Σ a_k z^k with |a_k| = 1, does max_{|z|=1} |P(z)| ≥ (1+c)√n for some c > 0? ANSWER: NO. Kahane (1980) constructed 'ultraflat' polynomials achieving (1+o(1))√n.

title: Erdős Problem #231: Abelian Squares in Strings
description: Must a string of length 2^k - 1 over k letters contain an abelian square? NO for k ≥ 4 (Keränen 1992).

title: Erdős Problem #232: Density of Unit-Distance Avoiding Sets
description: What is the maximum upper density of a measurable set in ℝ² with no two points at distance 1? Is m₁ ≤ 1/4? SOLVED: Yes, m₁ ≤ 0.247 < 1/4.

title: Erdős Problem #233: Sum of Squares of Prime Gaps
description: Prove that the sum of squares of prime gaps satisfies Σ dₙ² ≪ N(log N)², where dₙ = pₙ₊₁ - pₙ is the n-th prime gap.

title: Erdős Problem #235: Gaps Between Coprime Integers
description: Do gaps between integers coprime to Nₖ = 2·3·...·pₖ have a limiting distribution? YES - Hooley (1965) proved f(c) = 1 - e^{-c} (exponential distribution).

title: Erdős Problem #236: Growth of Prime Plus Power Representations
description: Is it true that f(n) = o(log n), where f(n) counts solutions to n = p + 2^k with p prime? Erdős proved infinitely many n have f(n) ≫ log log n, showing the conjecture is tight if true.

title: Erdős Problem #237: Prime Plus Set Representations
description: For A ⊆ ℕ with |A ∩ [1,N]| ≫ log(N), is limsup f(n) = ∞ where f(n) counts n = p + a? YES (Chen-Ding 2022), even for infinite A.

title: Erdős Problem #238: Consecutive Primes with Large Gaps
description: Can we always find long runs of consecutive primes where all gaps exceed a fixed constant?

title: Erdos Problem #239: Mean of Multiplicative Plus-Minus-One Functions
description: For multiplicative f : N -> {-1, 1}, does lim (1/N) sum_{n<=N} f(n) always exist? YES, proved by Wirsing (1967), generalized by Halasz (1968).

title: Erdős Problem #24: Pentagons in Triangle-Free Graphs
description: Does every triangle-free graph on 5n vertices contain at most n^5 copies of C5? Yes! Proved independently by Grzesik (2012) and Hatami et al. (2013) using flag algebras.

title: Erdős Problem #240: Gaps Between P-Smooth Numbers
description: Is there an infinite set of primes P such that gaps between consecutive P-smooth numbers → ∞? YES - Tijdeman (1973) proved for any ε > 0, exists infinite P with gaps ≫ aᵢ^{1-ε}.

title: Erdős Problem #242: The Erdős-Straus Conjecture
description: For every n > 2, can 4/n be expressed as a sum of three distinct unit fractions 1/x + 1/y + 1/z? This famous conjecture remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #243: Sylvester's Sequence Characterization
description: If a strictly increasing integer sequence has quadratic growth (aₙ/aₙ₋₁² → 1) and rational reciprocal sum, must it eventually follow the Sylvester recurrence?

title: Erdos Problem #244: Prime Plus Powers of C
description: For any real C > 1, does the set of integers of the form p + floor(C^k), for some prime p and k >= 0, have positive lower density? Originally asked to Erdos by Kalmar. Romanoff (1934) proved the answer is yes when C is a positive integer. Ding (2025) proved this holds for almost all C > 1.

title: Erdos Problem #245: Sumset Growth Ratio
description: For an infinite set A of natural numbers with zero density, the limsup of |A+A|/|A| is at least 3. Proved by Freiman (1973).

title: Erdős Problem #246: Completeness of {a^k b^l : k, l ≥ 0}
description: Let (a, b) = 1. The set {a^k b^l : k, l ≥ 0} is complete — every sufficiently large integer is a sum of distinct elements from this set. YES (Birch 1959).

title: Transcendence of Lacunary Sums
description: A problem about the transcendence of infinite series with lacunary (rapidly growing) exponents. Erdős proved transcendence under strong growth conditions, but the general conjecture remains open.

title: Erdos Problem #248: Bounded Prime Factors of Consecutive Integers
description: Are there infinitely many n such that the number of distinct prime divisors of n+k grows at most linearly in k for all k >= 1?

title: Erdos Problem #249: Irrationality of Totient Power Sum
description: Is the sum ∑ φ(n)/2^n irrational, where φ is Euler's totient function? Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #250: Irrationality of the Sigma-Power Series
description: Is the sum Σ σ(n)/2^n irrational? Yes, proved by Nesterenko using modular functions.

title: Erdős Problem #251: Irrationality of Σ pₙ/2ⁿ
description: Is the sum Σ pₙ/2ⁿ irrational, where pₙ is the nth prime? This OPEN problem asks about the arithmetic nature of a beautiful constant involving primes and powers of 2.

title: Erdős #252: Irrationality of Divisor Power Sums
description: For k ≥ 1, is the infinite sum Σ σₖ(n)/n! irrational? Proved for k ≤ 4; OPEN for k ≥ 5.

title: Erdős Problem #253: Subset Sums in Arithmetic Progressions
description: If a slowly growing sequence has subset sums hitting every arithmetic progression infinitely often, must all large integers be subset sums? Disproved by Cassels.

title: Erdős Problem #255: Discrepancy of Sequences in [0,1]
description: For any sequence in [0,1], must some interval have unbounded discrepancy? YES (Schmidt 1968). Tijdeman-Wagner (1980) proved discrepancy ≫ log N for almost all intervals.

title: Erdős Problem #256: Maxima of Products on the Unit Circle
description: Is log f(n) ≫ n^c for some c > 0, where f(n) = min over all a₁ ≤ ... ≤ aₙ of max_{|z|=1} |∏(1-z^{aᵢ})|? NO - Belov-Konyagin (1996) proved log f(n) ≪ (log n)⁴.

title: Erdős Problem #257: Irrationality of Lambert Sums
description: Is ∑_{n∈A} 1/(2^n - 1) irrational for every infinite set A? Solved for A = ℕ (Erdős 1948) and primes (Tao-Teräväinen 2025), open in general.

title: Erdős Problem #258: Irrationality of Divisor Sum Series
description: Is the sum of τ(n)/(a₁·...·aₙ) irrational for sequences with aₙ → ∞? Solved for monotone sequences by Erdős-Straus (1971).

title: Erdős Problem #259: Irrationality of Squarefree Sums
description: Is ∑_n μ(n)² · n/2^n irrational? Yes — proved by Chen and Ruzsa (1999). They showed any infinite subseries over squarefree numbers is irrational.

title: Erdős Problem #26: Thick Sequences and Behrend Sets
description: If A is a thick sequence (divergent reciprocal sum), must some shift A+k have density 1 coverage?

title: Erdős #260: Irrationality of Sparse Sequence Series
description: If a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ is increasing with aₙ/n → ∞, is ∑ aₙ/2^{aₙ} necessarily irrational?

title: Erdős Problem #262: Irrationality Sequences
description: How slowly can an 'irrationality sequence' grow? The sequence must satisfy limsup (log₂ log₂ a_n)/n ≥ 1 (Hančl 1991). Example: 2^{2^n} works; n! fails.

title: Erdős #263: Irrationality Sequences
description: Is 2^{2^n} an irrationality sequence? Must such sequences have a_n^{1/n} → ∞? A sequence is an irrationality sequence if all perturbations give irrational reciprocal sums.

title: Erdős Problem #264: Irrationality Sequences
description: A sequence aₙ is an 'irrationality sequence' if ∑1/(aₙ+bₙ) is irrational for all bounded bₙ. Is 2ⁿ or n! such a sequence? Kovač-Tao (2024) showed 2ⁿ is not; n! remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #265: Growth Rates of Sequences with Rational Sums
description: How fast can a sequence grow if both ∑ 1/aₙ and ∑ 1/(aₙ-1) are rational?

title: Erdős Problem #266: Shifted Sums and Irrationality
description: Stolarsky conjectured that for any convergent ∑1/aₙ, some shift t makes ∑1/(aₙ+t) irrational. Kovač-Tao (2024) disproved this: some sequences give rational sums for ALL rational shifts.

title: Erdős Problem #267: Irrationality of Fibonacci Reciprocal Sums
description: If n₁ < n₂ < ... is a sequence with n_{k+1}/n_k ≥ c > 1, must Σ 1/F_{n_k} be irrational? PARTIALLY SOLVED: Special cases proved, general conjecture OPEN.

title: Erdős #268: Interior of Harmonic Subseries Points
description: For X ⊆ ℝ^d of points (Σ 1/n, Σ 1/(n+1), ...) as A ranges over infinite sets with convergent harmonic sum, does X have nonempty interior? YES for all d ≥ 1 (Kovač 2024, Kovač-Tao 2024).

title: Erdos Problem #269: LCM Series Irrationality
description: For P a finite set of primes with |P|>=2, let {a_n} be the P-smooth numbers and L_n=[a_0,...,a_{n-1}]. Is the sum 1/L_1 + 1/L_2 + ... irrational? OPEN for finite P. Solved (always irrational) for infinite P.

title: Erdős #27: Almost Covering Systems
description: Does there exist C > 1 such that ε-almost covering systems exist with moduli in [N, CN] for all ε, N? Answer: NO (disproved by FFKPY).

title: Erdős Problem #270: Irrationality of Product-Reciprocal Series
description: For f(n) → ∞, is Σ 1/((n+1)⋯(n+f(n))) always irrational? NO - any positive real α is achievable. The non-decreasing case remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #271: Stanley Sequences
description: For any n, define the greedy AP-free sequence A(n) starting 0, n. Can the aₖ be explicitly determined? How fast do they grow? Partial results exist but the general problem is OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #272: Intersection Properties of Subsets
description: Maximum number of sets A_1,...,A_t ⊆ {1,...,N} with all pairwise intersections being non-empty arithmetic progressions. Answer: t ~ N²/2. Solved by Szabó (1999).

title: Erdős Problem #274: Exact Coverings by Cosets (Herzog-Schönheim)
description: Can a group be exactly covered by cosets with pairwise distinct indices? NO for abelian groups (Sun 2004). OPEN in general.

title: Erdős Problem #275: Covering Congruences
description: If r congruences {aᵢ (mod nᵢ)} cover 2^r consecutive integers, they cover all integers. This bound is tight: {2^(i-1) (mod 2^i)} shows 2^r-1 doesn't suffice.

title: Erdős Problem #277: Covering Systems and Abundancy
description: For every c > 0, does there exist n with σ(n) > cn but no covering system has all moduli dividing n? SOLVED: YES (Haight 1979).

title: Erdős Problem #280: Covering Congruences and Sieve Methods
description: For sequences n₁ < n₂ < ⋯ with nₖ > (1+ε)k log k, count integers avoiding specified congruence classes. Erdős conjectured this count is Ω(k), but Cambie found a trivial counterexample.

title: Erdős Problem #283: Egyptian Fractions and Polynomial Values
description: Can every sufficiently large m be represented as a sum of polynomial values p(n₁) + ... + p(nₖ) where the n's also form an Egyptian fraction summing to 1?
