Let ... be the maximal value of ... such that there exist ... with\[1={n_1}+\cdots+{n_k}.\]Is it true that\[f(k)=(1+o(1)){e-1...

title: Erdős Problem #285: Egyptian Fractions Asymptotics
description: Let f(k) be the minimal largest denominator in a k-term Egyptian fraction representation of 1. Is f(k) = (1+o(1))·e/(e-1)·k? YES — proved by Martin (2000). The constant e/(e-1) ≈ 1.582 comes from harmonic series structure.

title: Unit Fractions in Short Intervals
description: For k ≥ 2, can 1 be expressed as a sum of k distinct unit fractions with denominators in an interval of width (e-1+o(1))k? Croot (2001) proved the answer is yes.

title: Erdős Problem #287: Gap in Egyptian Fraction Representations of 1
description: For 1 = 1/n₁ + ⋯ + 1/nₖ with distinct integers, must max(nᵢ₊₁ - nᵢ) ≥ 3? The example 1 = 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 shows 3 is optimal. Gap ≥ 2 is proven. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #29: Explicit Economical Additive Basis
description: Is there an explicit construction of A ⊆ ℕ such that A + A = ℕ but r_A(n) = o(n^ε) for every ε > 0? SOLVED by Jain-Pham-Sawhney-Zakharov (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #290: Denominator Non-Monotonicity in Harmonic Sums
description: Must there exist b > a such that adding 1/(b+1) to ∑_{a≤n≤b} 1/n decreases the reduced denominator? SOLVED: YES (van Doorn 2024) with b(a) < 4.374a.

title: Erdős Problem #291: Harmonic Number Divisibility
description: Do both gcd(a_n, L_n) = 1 and gcd(a_n, L_n) > 1 occur infinitely often, where H_n = a_n/L_n? Part 2 trivially YES; Part 1 OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #292: Egyptian Fractions Summing to 1
description: Let A be the set of n such that there exist 1 ≤ m₁ < ... < mₖ = n with Σ(1/mᵢ) = 1. Does A have density 1? YES (Martin 2000).

title: Missing Denominators in Egyptian Fraction Decompositions
description: Let v(k) be the smallest integer not appearing in any k-term Egyptian fraction decomposition of 1. Current bounds: e^{ck²} ≤ v(k) ≤ k·c₀^{2^k}. The gap between these bounds is enormous.

title: Erdős Problem #294: Egyptian Fractions and the t(N) Function
description: Let t(N) be the least t with no Egyptian representation of 1 using denominators in [t,N]. Estimate t(N).

title: Erdős Problem #295: Egyptian Fractions with Large Denominators
description: Let k(N) be the smallest number of terms needed to write 1 as a sum of distinct unit fractions with denominators ≥ N. Is k(N) - (e-1)N → ∞?

title: Erdős Problem #296: Disjoint Unit Fraction Partitions
description: How many disjoint sets A₁,...,Aₖ ⊆ {1,...,N} can have Σ 1/n = 1 for each set? Erdős asked if k(N) = o(log N). Answer: NO. Hunter-Sawhney (via Bloom 2021) proved k(N) = (1-o(1))·log N.

title: Erdős Problem #297: Counting Egyptian Fraction Representations of 1
description: How many A ⊆ {1,...,N} satisfy Σ 1/n = 1? Answer: 2^{(0.91...+o(1))N}. Solved independently by three teams in 2024.

title: Erdős Problem #298: Unit Fractions from Sets of Positive Density
description: Does every set A ⊆ ℕ of positive density contain some finite S ⊂ A such that ∑_{n ∈ S} 1/n = 1? YES (Thomas Bloom, 2021). Prize: $500. A Lean 3 formalization exists at github.com/b-mehta/unit-fractions.

title: Erdős Problem #299: Bounded Gap Sequences and Unit Fractions
description: Is there an infinite sequence with bounded gaps such that no finite sum of reciprocals equals 1? The answer is NO, as proved by Bloom (2021).

title: Erdős Problem #3: Arithmetic Progressions in Large Sets
description: If A ⊆ ℕ has divergent reciprocal sum, must A contain arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions? OPEN with $5,000 prize. Connected to Szemerédi's theorem and Green-Tao.

title: Erdős Problem #30: Sidon Sets
description: Is h(N) = N^{1/2} + O_ε(N^ε) where h(N) is the maximum Sidon set size in {1,...,N}? OPEN with $1,000 prize. Best upper bound has N^{1/4} error term.

title: Erdős Problem #300: Maximum Subsets Avoiding Unit Fraction Sum 1
description: Let A(N) be the max size of A ⊆ {1,...,N} with no subset summing to 1 via unit fractions. SOLVED: A(N) = (1 - 1/e + o(1))N (Liu-Sawhney 2024). Erdős-Graham conjecture A(N) ≈ N disproved by Croot (2003).

title: Erdős Problem #302: Unit Fraction Sum-Free Sets
description: Let f(N) be the largest subset of {1,...,N} with no solution to 1/a = 1/b + 1/c. Is f(N) = (1/2+o(1))N? Answer: NO. Known: 5/8 ≤ lim f(N)/N ≤ 9/10. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #303: Monochromatic Unit Fraction Solutions
description: In any finite colouring of the integers, does there exist a monochromatic solution to 1/a = 1/b + 1/c with distinct a, b, c? A Ramsey-theoretic problem solved affirmatively by Brown and Rödl (1991).

title: Erdős Problem #304: Egyptian Fractions Complexity
description: For integers 1 ≤ a < b, let N(a,b) denote the minimal number of distinct unit fractions summing to a/b. Let N(b) = max N(a,b). Erdős (1950) proved log log b ≪ N(b) ≪ log b/log log b. Vose (1985) improved to N(b) ≪ √(log b). Open: Is N(b) ≪ log log b?

title: Maximum Denominator in Egyptian Fraction Representations
description: For integers 1 ≤ a < b, let D(a,b) be the minimum maximum denominator needed to represent a/b as an Egyptian fraction. Is D(b) = max_a D(a,b) bounded by b(log b)^{1+o(1)}? Solved by Yokota (1988), improved by Liu-Sawhney (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #306: Egyptian Fractions with Semiprime Denominators
description: Can every positive rational a/b with b squarefree be expressed as an Egyptian fraction where each denominator is a product of exactly 2 distinct primes? The 2-prime case is OPEN; the 3-prime case for integers was solved by Butler, Erdős, and Graham (2015).

title: Erdős #307: Prime Reciprocal Products
description: Are there two finite sets of primes P, Q with (Σ 1/p)(Σ 1/q) = 1? Prime version: OPEN. Coprime version: SOLVED by Cambie with (1 + 1/5)(1/2 + 1/3) = 1.

title: Erdős Problem #308: Representable Integers via Unit Fractions
description: What integers can be written as sums of distinct unit fractions 1/1 + 1/2 + ... with denominators ≤ N? Croot (1999) proved the representable set is contiguous and f(N) ≈ ⌊H_N⌋.

title: Erdős Problem #309: Integers as Sums of Distinct Unit Fractions
description: How many integers can be written as sums of distinct unit fractions with denominators from {1,...,N}? Answer: Θ(log N) such integers, answering Erdős's question negatively.

title: Erdős Problem #31: Additive Complements
description: For any infinite A ⊆ ℕ, there exists B with density 0 such that A + B covers all but finitely many positive integers.

title: Erdos Problem #310: Unit Fractions from Dense Subsets
description: For any dense subset A of {1,...,N}, can we find S in A such that the sum of 1/n for n in S equals a/b with bounded denominator? YES, proved by Liu-Sawhney (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #312: Subset Sum of Unit Fractions
description: Does there exist c > 0 such that for K > 1, every large multiset with Σ(1/n) > K has a subset summing to within exp(-cK) of 1?

title: Erdős Problem #314: Harmonic Sum Error Term
description: Let m(n) be minimal with partial harmonic sum ≥ 1, and ε(n) the overshoot. Is lim inf n²ε(n) = 0? SOLVED by Lim-Steinerberger (2024): YES, with infinitely many n achieving ε(n)n² ≪ (log log n / log n)^{1/2}.

title: Erdős Problem #315: Sylvester's Sequence and the Vardi Constant
description: For Sylvester's sequence u_n with Σ 1/u_n = 1, is lim u_n^{1/2^n} = c₀ ≈ 1.264 the maximum growth rate among all such sequences? YES - proved by Kamio and Li-Tang (2025).

title: Erdős Problem #316: Partitioning Sets by Reciprocal Sums
description: Can every finite set with reciprocal sum < 2 be partitioned into two parts each with sum < 1? Answer: NO - disproved by Sándor (1997).

title: Erdős Problem #317: Signed Unit Fraction Approximations
description: Is there c > 0 such that for every n, we can find δ_k ∈ {-1,0,1} with 0 < |∑δ_k/k| < c/2^n? Also: for large n, must nonzero such sums exceed 1/lcm(1,...,n)? OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #318: Signed Unit Fractions with Zero Sum
description: Given A ⊆ ℕ and f:A→{±1}, must ∃ finite S ⊂ A with ∑f(n)/n = 0? YES for arithmetic progressions.

title: Erdős Problem #32: Additive Complements of Primes
description: Is there a set A with |A ∩ [1,N]| = o((log N)²) such that every large integer is p + a for prime p and a ∈ A? Partially solved: Ruzsa proved O(ω(N)·log N) is achievable and Ω(e^γ·log N) is necessary. The $50 question of whether O(log N) is achievable remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #320: Distinct Sums of Unit Fractions
description: Estimate S(N), the number of distinct sums ∑_{n∈A} 1/n for A ⊆ {1,...,N}. OPEN - Bleicher-Erdős (1975-76) gave bounds with iterated logarithms. BGMS (2025) improved the lower bound.

title: Erdős Problem #322: Representations as Sums of k-th Powers
description: Does r_k(n) > n^c for infinitely many n, where r_k(n) counts representations of n as sum of k k-th powers? k=3: YES (Mahler 1936). k≥4: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #325: Sums of Three k-th Powers
description: Let f_{k,3}(x) count integers ≤ x that are sums of three k-th powers. Is it true that f_{k,3}(x) ≫ x^{3/k} for k ≥ 3?

title: Erdős Problem #326: Additive Bases and Non-Convergent Subsequences
description: Let A be an additive basis of order 2. Must there exist a subset B which is also a basis such that the growth ratio of B has no limit?

title: Erdős Problem #328: Partitioning Sets with Bounded Representation Function
description: Can sets A with bounded convolution r_A ≤ C be partitioned into pieces with strictly smaller convolution? DISPROVED: NO for all C (Nešetřil-Rödl 1985).

title: Erdős Problem #329: Maximum Density of Sidon Sets
description: For a Sidon set A (where all pairwise sums are distinct), how large can limsup |A ∩ {1,...,N}| / √N be? Known bounds: 1/√2 ≤ sup ≤ 1. The exact supremum remains OPEN.

title: Erdős #33: Additive Complements of Squares
description: For sets A such that every integer is n² + a for some a ∈ A, what is the minimum possible density? Best known: liminf ≥ 4/π ≈ 1.273 and limsup ≤ 2φ^(5/2) ≈ 6.66.

title: Erdős Problem #331: Common Differences in Dense Sets
description: For A, B ⊆ ℕ with |A ∩ {1,...,N}| ≫ N^{1/2} and |B ∩ {1,...,N}| ≫ N^{1/2}, must there be infinitely many common differences a₁-a₂ = b₁-b₂ ≠ 0? DISPROVED by Ruzsa.

title: Erdős Problem #333: Sparse Sumset Bases
description: For any zero-density A ⊆ ℕ, does there exist B with A ⊆ B+B and |B ∩ [1,N]| = o(√N)? NO - Erdős-Newman (1977) Theorem 2 implies counterexamples exist, though this was overlooked.

title: Erdős Problem #334: Smooth Number Representation
description: Find the best function f(n) such that every n can be written as n = a + b where both a and b are f(n)-smooth (not divisible by any prime p > f(n)).

title: Erdős Problem #336: Additive Bases and Exact Order
description: Find lim h(r)/r² where h(r) is the maximal exact order of a basis of order r. Known: 1/3 ≤ lim ≤ 1/2. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #337: Additive Bases and Sumset Growth
description: For sparse additive bases A, is |A+A ∩ [1,N]| / |A ∩ [1,N]| → ∞? Answer: NO (Turjányi 1984). Generalized to h-fold sumsets by Ruzsa-Turjányi.

title: Erdős Problem #338: Restricted Order of Additive Bases
description: What are the necessary and sufficient conditions for an additive basis to have a restricted order? Can the restricted order be bounded in terms of the order? When does restricted order equal order?

title: Erdős Problem #339: Additive Bases and Distinct Element Sums
description: If A is a basis of order r, must sums of r DISTINCT elements have positive lower density? YES - proved by Hegyvári-Hennecart-Plagne (2003). Also: upper density is preserved.

title: Erdos Problem #34: Consecutive Sums in Permutations
description: Is S(pi) = o(n^2) for all permutations? DISPROVED - there exist permutations with S(pi) >= n^2/4.

title: Erdős Problem #343: Subcompleteness of Dense Multisets
description: If A ⊆ ℕ has positive lower density (|A ∩ {1,...,N}| ≫ N), must P(A) contain an infinite arithmetic progression? SOLVED: YES (Szemerédi-Vu 2006), threshold is sharp (Folkman 1966).

title: Subcomplete Sequences and Arithmetic Progressions
description: If A ⊆ ℕ has counting function |A ∩ {1,...,N}| ≫ N^{1/2}, must the subset sums P(A) contain an infinite arithmetic progression? Solved by Szemerédi-Vu (2006).

title: Erdős Problem #348: Robustness of Complete Sequences
description: For what values of 0 ≤ m < n is there a complete sequence that remains complete after removing any m elements but becomes incomplete after removing some n elements?

title: Erdős #35: Schnirelmann Density and Additive Bases
description: If B is an additive basis of order k, does d_s(A+B) ≥ α + α(1-α)/k hold for all A?

title: Erdős Problem #350: Sum of Reciprocals of Dissociated Sets
description: If A is a finite dissociated set (all subset sums distinct) of positive integers, prove that the sum of reciprocals is less than 2. Proved by Ryavec.

title: Erdős Problem #351: Strong Completeness of Polynomial-Reciprocal Sequences
description: Is {p(n) + 1/n : n in N} strongly complete for all polynomials p(x)? General case open; solved for p(x) = x and p(x) = x².

title: Erdős Problem #352: Triangles of Area 1 in Measurable Sets
description: Is there c > 0 such that every measurable set A in R^2 with measure >= c contains a triangle of area 1? Conjectured c = 4pi/sqrt(27). Open problem.

title: Erdős Problem #353: Geometric Configurations in Sets of Infinite Measure
description: Let A ⊆ ℝ² have infinite Lebesgue measure. Must A contain vertices of an isosceles trapezoid, triangle, or right triangle of area 1? SOLVED: YES for all three (Koizumi 2025). Parallelograms can fail (Kovač 2023).

title: Erdős Problem #354: Completeness of Binary Floor Sequences
description: Let α, β > 0 with α/β irrational. Is the multiset {⌊2ᵏα⌋} ∪ {⌊2ᵏβ⌋} complete (representing all large integers)? OPEN in general.

title: Erdős Problem #355: Lacunary Sequences and Rational Representation
description: Can a lacunary sequence's reciprocal sums cover all rationals in an open interval? YES for lacunarity constant in (1,2), proved by van Doorn and Kovač (2025).

title: Consecutive Sums in Strictly Increasing Sequences
description: Is there c > 0 such that strictly increasing sequences a₁ < ... < aₖ ≤ n can achieve cn² distinct consecutive sums? SOLVED: YES (Beker 2023). The trivial sequence {1,...,n} fails with only O(n) distinct sums.

title: Erdős #357: Distinct Consecutive Sums
description: Let f(n) = max k for 1 ≤ a₁ < ... < aₖ ≤ n with all consecutive sums distinct. Is f(n) = o(n)? Known: f(n) ≥ (2+o(1))√n.

title: Erdos Problem #358: Sums of Consecutive Terms
description: Does there exist an infinite sequence A such that the count of representations of n as a sum of consecutive terms tends to infinity? Or even f(n) >= 2 for all large n?

title: Erdos Problem #359: MacMahon's Prime Numbers of Measurement
description: What is the density of MacMahon's sequence where each term is the smallest integer not expressible as a sum of consecutive earlier terms? Conjectured: a_k ~ (k log k) / (log log k).

title: Erdős Problem #360: Partition Sum-Free Classes
description: Determine the growth rate of f(n), the minimum number of classes to partition {1,...,n-1} so n is not a sum of distinct elements from any class. Solved: f(n) ≍ n^{1/3}(n/φ(n)) / (log n)^{1/3}(log log n)^{2/3}.

title: Erdős Problem #362: Subset Sum Concentration
description: For a finite set A of size N, how many subsets can sum to a fixed value t? Sárközy-Szemerédi (1965) proved the bound 2^N / N^(3/2). With fixed cardinality, Halász (1977) proved 2^N / N². Stanley (1980) found the extremal set.

title: Erdős Problem #363: Square Products from Disjoint Intervals
description: Are there only finitely many collections of disjoint intervals I₁,...,Iₙ with |Iᵢ| ≥ 4 such that the product ∏ᵢ ∏_{m ∈ Iᵢ} m is a perfect square?

title: Erdős Problem #364: Consecutive Powerful Numbers
description: A positive integer n is powerful if p | n implies p² | n. Are there three consecutive powerful numbers? The quadruple case is impossible (proved), but the triple case remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #365: Consecutive Powerful Numbers
description: Do all pairs of consecutive powerful numbers come from Pell equations? Must one be a square? Is the count O((log x)^O(1))?

title: Erdős Problem #366: Consecutive k-Full Numbers
description: Are there any 2-full (powerful) n such that n+1 is 3-full (cubeful)? A number is k-full if every prime factor appears with multiplicity at least k. Known: (8,9) and (12167,12168) are 3-full/2-full pairs, but no 2-full/3-full pairs are known.

title: Erdős Problem #367: Products of 2-Full Parts
description: Study the growth of products of 2-full parts over consecutive integers.

title: Erdős Problem #368: Largest Prime Factor of n(n+1)
description: Study of F(n), the largest prime factor of n(n+1). Pólya proved F(n) → ∞; Mahler showed F(n) ≫ log log n; Pasten (2024) improved to F(n) ≫ (log log n)²/(log log log n). Erdős conjectured F(n) ≈ (log n)².

title: Erdős Problem #37: Essential Components and Lacunary Sets
description: Can a lacunary set A ⊂ ℕ be an essential component? NO (Ruzsa 1987). Essential components need |A ∩ {1,...,N}| ≥ (log N)^{1+c}, but lacunary sets have only O(log N) elements. Open: Is {2^m · 3^n} essential?

title: Consecutive Smooth Numbers
description: Are there infinitely many n such that both n and n+1 have their largest prime factor less than their square root? Steinerberger found an elegant solution using n = m² - 1.

title: Erdős #371: Density of P(n) < P(n+1)
description: Let P(n) be the largest prime factor of n. Show that {n : P(n) < P(n+1)} has density 1/2. Conditionally solved by Wang (2021); logarithmic density proved by Teräväinen (2018).

title: Erdős Problem #372: Descending Largest Prime Factors
description: Let P(n) denote the largest prime factor of n. Are there infinitely many n such that P(n) > P(n+1) > P(n+2)?

title: Erdos Problem #373: Factorials as Products of Factorials
description: Show that n! = a_1! * a_2! * ... * a_k! with n-1 > a_1 >= ... >= a_k >= 2 has only finitely many solutions. Conditionally solved under ABC conjecture (Luca 2007).

title: Erdos Problem #375: Grimm's Conjecture on Consecutive Composites
description: For any k consecutive composites n+1,...,n+k, can we assign distinct prime divisors? Open - if true, implies strong prime gap bounds.

title: Erdős Problem #376: Central Binomial Coefficients Coprime to 105
description: Are there infinitely many n such that C(2n,n) is coprime to 105 = 3×5×7? OPEN for three primes. EGRS (1975) solved the two-prime case.

title: Erdős Problem #377: Primes Not Dividing Central Binomial
description: Is there an absolute constant C such that ∑_{p≤n, p∤C(2n,n)} 1/p ≤ C for all n? The main conjecture is OPEN, but EGRS75 proved f(n) averages to γ₀ = ∑log(k)/2^k and is ≤ c·log(log(n)) for c < 1.

title: Erdos Problem #378: Density of Squarefree Binomial Coefficients
description: Does the density of n for which C(n,k) is squarefree for at least r values of k exist and is it positive? YES to both, resolved via Granville-Ramare.

title: Erdos Problem #379: Binomial Coefficients and Prime Power Divisibility
description: Let S(n) be the largest s such that every C(n,k) for 1 <= k < n is divisible by some p^s. Is limsup S(n) = infinity?

title: Erdős #38: Essential Components and Density Boosting
description: Does there exist a set B that is NOT an additive basis but still has the density-boosting property: for any set A with Schnirelmann density α, some translate A ∪ (A+b) achieves density ≥ α + f(α)?

title: Erdős Problem #381: Counting Highly Composite Numbers
description: Is Q(x) ≫_k (log x)^k for every k, where Q(x) counts highly composite numbers up to x? DISPROVED by Nicolas (1971) - Q(x) has polynomial growth in log x.

title: Erdos Problem #382: Prime Powers in Factorial Products
description: For intervals [u,v] where the largest prime dividing the product u(u+1)...v has exponent >= 2: Is v-u = v^o(1)? Can v-u be arbitrarily large? OPEN. Ramachandra: v-u <= v^{1/2+o(1)}.

title: Erdős Problem #383: Prime Divisors of Consecutive Squares
description: For every k, are there infinitely many primes p such that p is the largest prime divisor of ∏_{i=0}^k (p² + i)?

title: Erdős Problem #384: Prime Divisors of Binomial Coefficients
description: If 1 < k < n-1 then C(n,k) is divisible by a prime p < n/2. SOLVED by Ecklund (1969). The only exception is C(7,3) = 35 = 5 × 7.

title: Erdős Problem #385: Composites and Least Prime Divisors
description: Is F(n) = max{m + p(m) : m < n composite} greater than n for all large n, where p(m) is the least prime divisor?

title: Erdős Problem #387: Divisors of Binomial Coefficients Near n
description: Is there an absolute constant c > 0 such that for all 1 ≤ k < n, the binomial coefficient C(n,k) has a divisor in the interval (cn, n]?

title: Erdős Problem #39: Infinite Sidon Set Growth
description: Does there exist an infinite Sidon set with counting function approaching N^{1/2}?

title: Erdős Problem #391
description:

Random Solved
Random Open

Let ... be maximal such that there is a representation\[n!=a_1\cdots a_n\]with .... Obtain good bounds for .... In particular...

title: Erdős Problem #392: Optimal Factorization of n!
description: Let A(n) be the minimum number of factors needed to write n! = a₁...aₜ with each aᵢ ≤ n². Then A(n) = n/2 - n/(2 log n) + o(n/log n).

title: Erdős Problem #393: Factorial Factorization Span
description: Let f(n) = minimal m such that n! = a₁·...·aₜ with a₁ < ... < aₜ = a₁ + m. Study the behavior of f(n). Known: F_m(N) = o(N), conditional f(n) → ∞.

title: Erdős Problem #394: Divisibility by Consecutive Integer Products
description: Let t_k(n) be the least m with n | m(m+1)···(m+k-1). Erdős-Hall (1978) proved Σ t₂(n) ≪ (log log log x / log log x)x². Questions about x²/(log x)^c bounds and hierarchy Σ t_{k+1} = o(Σ t_k) remain OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #395: Reverse Littlewood-Offord Problem
description: For unit complex vectors, is P(|ε₁z₁ + ... + εₙzₙ| ≤ √2) ≥ c/n? YES (HJNS 2024).

title: Erdős Problem #397: Products of Central Binomial Coefficients
description: Are there only finitely many solutions to products of central binomial coefficients being equal? Disproved by Somani (2026).

title: Erdős Problem #398: The Brocard-Ramanujan Conjecture
description: Are the only solutions to n! + 1 = m² when n = 4, 5, 7? This classic conjecture, dating to Brocard (1876) and Ramanujan, remains open despite computational verification to 10^9.

title: Erdős Problem #399: Factorial Diophantine Equations
description: Is it true that there are no solutions to n! = x^k ± y^k with xy > 1 and k > 2? Disproved by Barfield: 10! = 48^4 - 36^4.

title: Erdős Problem #4: Large Prime Gaps
description: For any C > 0, are there infinitely many n with p_{n+1} - p_n > C·f(n) where f(n) involves iterated logs? SOLVED: YES.

title: Erdős Problem #401: Factorial Divisibility with Prime Products
description: Does there exist f(r) → ∞ such that for infinitely many n, there exist a₁, a₂ with a₁ + a₂ > n + f(r)·log(n) where a₁!·a₂! | n!·2ⁿ·3ⁿ·...·pᵣⁿ? YES (Barreto-Leeham 2026). The 'for all large n' version is FALSE (Sothanaphan).

title: Graham's GCD Conjecture
description: For any finite set A ⊂ ℕ, there exist a, b ∈ A such that gcd(a, b) ≤ a/|A|. Graham's conjecture was proved by Balasubramanian and Soundararajan in 1996.

title: Erdős Problem #403: Powers of 2 as Sums of Distinct Factorials
description: Does 2^m = a₁! + a₂! + ... + aₖ! (with distinct aᵢ) have only finitely many solutions? YES - the largest is 2^7 = 2! + 3! + 5! = 128 (Lin/Frankl 1976).

title: Erdős Problem #404: Prime Power Divisibility of Factorial Sums
description: For which (a, p) is there a bound on k such that p^k divides some sum of factorials starting at a?

title: Erdős Problem #405: Factorial Plus Power Equals Prime Power
description: Let p be an odd prime. Is it true that the equation (p-1)! + a^{p-1} = p^k has only finitely many solutions? Yu-Liu (1996) proved there are exactly three solutions: 2! + 1² = 3, 2! + 5² = 27, and 4! + 1⁴ = 25.

title: Erdős Problem #407: Newman's Conjecture on 2^a + 3^b + 2^c·3^d
description: Is w(n) bounded, where w(n) counts representations n = 2^a + 3^b + 2^c·3^d? Solved: w(n) ≤ 9 always, w(n) ≤ 4 for large n (EGST 1988, Bajpai-Bennett 2024).

title: Erdős Problem #408: Iterated Totient Function
description: Does f(n)/log(n) have a distribution function, where f(n) is the number of iterations of Euler's totient needed to reach 1? EGPS (1990) proved YES conditionally on Elliott-Halberstam.

title: Erdős Problem #41: B_h Sequences and Density Bounds
description: For infinite B_3 sets (distinct triple sums), is liminf |A ∩ {1,...,N}| / N^(1/3) = 0?

title: Erdős Problem #410: Iterated Sum of Divisors Growth
description: Does lim_{k → ∞} σₖ(n)^{1/k} = ∞ for all n ≥ 2, where σₖ is the k-th iterate of the sum of divisors function?

title: Erdos Problem #412: Iterated Sum of Divisors Convergence
description: Do all iterated sum-of-divisors sequences eventually meet? For every m,n ≥ 2, is there i,j such that σᵢ(m) = σⱼ(n)? Open. Selfridge provided evidence suggesting NO.

title: Erdős Problem #413: Barriers for the Omega Function
description: Are there infinitely many n such that m + ω(m) ≤ n for all m < n?

title: Erdős Problem #415: Ordering Patterns in Euler's Totient Function
description: Let F(n) = largest k such that ALL k! ordering patterns appear in some φ(m+1),...,φ(m+k). Erdős proved F(n) ≍ log log log n. The exact constant and which pattern fails first remain OPEN.

title: Counting Totient Values
description: Let V(x) count the number of n ≤ x such that φ(m) = n is solvable. Does V(2x)/V(x) → 2? Is there an asymptotic formula for V(x)? Despite remarkable progress by Pillai, Erdős, Maier-Pomerance, and Ford, both questions remain open.

title: Erdős Problem #417: Counting Totient Values
description: Does the limit V(x)/V'(x) exist, where V'(x) counts distinct totients from inputs ≤ x and V(x) counts all totient values ≤ x?

title: Erdos Problem #418: Non-Cototients
description: Are there infinitely many positive integers not of the form n - phi(n)? Yes - integers 2^k * 509203 are non-cototients.

title: Erdős Problem #419: Limit Points of τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!)
description: What is the set of limit points of τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!)? SOLVED: The limit points are exactly {1} ∪ {1 + 1/k : k ≥ 1} = {1, 2, 3/2, 4/3, 5/4, ...}.

title: Erdős Problem #420: Divisor Function Ratios for Factorials
description: For F(f,n) = τ((n+⌊f(n)⌋)!)/τ(n!), study when F→∞ and when F is dense in (1,∞). Partially solved by EGIP96: liminf F(c log n, n) = 1 and lim F(n^{4/9}, n) = ∞.

title: Erdős Problem #421: Distinct Products in Dense Sequences
description: Is there a strictly increasing sequence d₁ < d₂ < ... with density 1 such that all interval products ∏_{u ≤ i ≤ v} d_i are distinct?

title: Erdős Problem #425: Multiplicative Sidon Sets
description: Let F(n) be the maximum size of A ⊆ {1,...,n} such that all pairwise products ab (a < b) are distinct. Erdős proved π(n) + c₁·n^(3/4)·(log n)^(-3/2) ≤ F(n) ≤ π(n) + c₂·n^(3/4)·(log n)^(-3/2). The exact constant c (if it exists) is unknown. Alexander disproved the real version conjecture.

title: Erdős Problem #426: Unique Subgraphs
description: Can a graph on n vertices have ≫ 2^(n choose 2)/n! unique subgraphs? Answer: NO (Bradač-Christoph 2024). Unique subgraphs are rare.

title: Erdős Problem #427: Divisibility of Prime Sums
description: Is it true that for every n and d, there exists k such that d divides the sum p_{n+1} + ... + p_{n+k}, where p_r denotes the r-th prime? Solved by Pilatte using Shiu's theorem on strings of congruent primes.

title: Erdős Problem #429: Sparse Admissible Sets and Prime Shifts
description: Is sparsity + admissibility sufficient for a prime shift? Answer: NO (Weisenberg 2024 constructed arbitrarily sparse admissible sets with no prime shift).

title: Erdős Problem #431: Inverse Goldbach Problem
description: Are there two infinite sets A and B such that A + B agrees with the set of prime numbers up to finitely many exceptions? Known as Ostmann's 'inverse Goldbach problem'. The answer is conjectured to be NO.

title: Erdős Problem #433: Maximum Frobenius Numbers
description: For g(k,n) = max{G(A) : A ⊆ {1,...,n}, |A| = k, gcd(A) = 1}, prove that g(k,n) ~ n²/(k-1). SOLVED by Dixmier (1990) who gave precise bounds.

title: Erdős #434: Extremal Frobenius Problem
description: Which k-subset of {1,...,n} maximizes non-representable integers? Answer: {n-k+1,...,n} (Kiss 2002).

title: Erdős Problem #435: Binomial Coefficient Representation
description: For n not a prime power, the largest integer not representable as Σ c_i·C(n,i) with c_i≥0 equals Σ_k (Σ_{d≤a_k} C(n,p_k^d))·(p_k-1) - n. SOLVED by Hwang-Song (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #436: Consecutive kth Power Residues
description: For prime p and k,m ≥ 2, let r(k,m,p) be the minimal r such that r,...,r+m-1 are kth power residues mod p. Let Λ(k,m) = lim sup r(k,m,p). Hildebrand (1991) proved Λ(k,2) finite for all k. Λ(k,3) for odd k ≥ 5 remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #437: Square Partial Products
description: For 1 ≤ a₁ < ... < aₖ ≤ x, how many partial products can be squares? Can there be > x^(1-ε) squares? YES, proved by Bui-Pratt-Zaharescu (2024) with precise bounds via hyperelliptic curves.

title: Erdős Problem #438: Square-Free Sumsets
description: How large can A ⊆ {1,...,N} be if A+A contains no square numbers? The maximum density is exactly 11/32, achieved by a mod 32 construction (Massias) and proved tight by Khalfalah-Lodha-Szemerédi (2002).

title: Erdős Problem #439: Monochromatic Solutions to x + y = z²
description: In any finite coloring of the integers, must there be distinct x ≠ y of the same color with x + y a perfect square? SOLVED by Khalfalah-Szemerédi (2006): YES.

title: Erdős Problem #44: Extending Sidon Sets
description: Can any Sidon set be extended to achieve near-optimal density (1-eps)sqrt(M)? An OPEN conjecture with auxiliary results about Sidon set bounds proved.

title: Erdős Problem #440: LCM of Consecutive Sequence Elements
description: For infinite sequence A, let A(x) count indices i with lcm(aᵢ, aᵢ₊₁) ≤ x. Is A(x) = O(√x)? YES, and liminf A(x)/√x ≤ 1 always, with equality for A = ℕ (Erdős-Szemerédi 1980).

title: Erdős Problem #441: LCM-Bounded Subsets
description: Find the maximum size g(N) of A ⊆ {1,...,N} such that lcm(a,b) ≤ N for all a,b ∈ A. Is Erdős' construction optimal? Answer: NO - Chen and Dai proved for infinitely many N, the optimal set is strictly larger than Erdős' construction. The asymptotic g(N) ~ (9N/8)^{1/2} is known.

title: Erdős #442: LCM Sums Over Dense Subsets
description: If a subset A ⊆ ℕ has reciprocal sum growing faster than log log x, must the normalized LCM sum diverge? NO — Tao (2024) constructed a counterexample and proved the threshold is sharp.

title: Erdős Problem #443: Common Products k(m-k) and l(n-l)
description: For m,n ≥ 1, how large can the intersection |{k(m-k) : 1≤k≤m/2} ∩ {l(n-l) : 1≤l≤n/2}| be? Can it be arbitrarily large? Is it ≤(mn)^{o(1)}? YES to both - proved by Hegyvári (2025) and Cambie.

title: Erdős Problem #444: Generalized Divisor Functions
description: Let A ⊆ ℕ be infinite and d_A(n) count divisors of n in A. Is limsup max d_A(n) / (Σ 1/a)^k = ∞ for all k? SOLVED: YES by Erdős-Sárközy (1980) - the maximum grows faster than any power of the harmonic sum.

title: Erdős Problem #445: Multiplicative Inverses in Short Intervals
description: For c > 1/2, can we find a,b ∈ (n, n+p^c) with ab ≡ 1 (mod p) for large primes p? Heath-Brown proved this for c > 3/4 using Kloosterman sums. The range c ∈ (1/2, 3/4] remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #446: Density of Integers with Divisors in (n, 2n)
description: Let δ(n) denote the density of integers divisible by some d ∈ (n, 2n). Ford (2008) proved δ(n) ≍ 1/((log n)^α (log log n)^{3/2}) where α ≈ 0.08607, and disproved δ₁(n) = o(δ(n)).

title: Erdős Problem #447: Union-Free Collections of Sets
description: How large can a union-free collection ℱ of subsets of [n] be (no A ∪ B = C with distinct A, B, C ∈ ℱ)? Kleitman (1971) proved |ℱ| < (1+o(1)) C(n, ⌊n/2⌋).

title: Erdős Problem #448: Divisors in Dyadic Intervals
description: Is τ⁺(n) < ε·τ(n) for almost all n? NO (DISPROVED) - Erdős-Tenenbaum showed exceptions have positive density.

title: Close Divisor Pairs
description: Erdős Problem #449 asks whether 'close' divisor pairs (d₁, d₂) with d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁ are rare compared to total divisors. Specifically: is r(n) < ε·τ(n) for almost all n? The answer is NO - for any K > 0, a positive density set has r(n) > K·τ(n).

title: Erdős #45: Monochromatic Egyptian Fractions
description: For k ≥ 2, does there exist n_k such that any k-coloring of proper divisors D of n_k contains a monochromatic D' with Σ 1/d = 1? YES (Croot). Bounds: n_k ≈ exp(C^k) doubly exponential (Sawhney).

title: Erdős Problem #452: Largest Interval with ω(n) > log log n
description: Let ω(n) count distinct prime factors. What is the largest interval I ⊆ [x,2x] where ω(n) > log log n for all n ∈ I? Known: |I| ≥ log x/(log log x)². Conjecture: (log x)^k is achievable for any k.

title: Erdős Problem #453: Prime Products and Squares
description: Is it true that for all large n, there exists i < n with p_n² < p_{n+i}·p_{n-i}? SOLVED: NO. Pomerance (1979) proved infinitely many n have p_n² > p_{n+i}·p_{n-i} for all i < n, using convex hull geometry on log primes.

title: Erdős #454: Prime Sum Deviations
description: Let f(n) = min_{i<n} (p_{n+i} + p_{n-i}). Is limsup(f(n) - 2p_n) = ∞? Pomerance (1979) proved limsup ≥ 2. The problem remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #455: Monotone Prime Gap Sequences
description: If primes q₁ < q₂ < ... have non-decreasing gaps, must q_n grow faster than n²?

title: LCM Inequality for Primes
description: Let lcm(1,...,n) denote the least common multiple of {1,...,n}. Is it true that for all k ≥ 1, lcm(1,...,p_{k+1}-1) < p_k · lcm(1,...,p_k)? Erdős and Graham call this 'almost certainly' true, but proving it requires something close to Legendre's conjecture.

title: Erdős Problem #459: Estimate f(u) - Smooth Number Gaps
description: Let f(u) be the largest v such that no m ∈ (u,v) is smooth with respect to u. Estimate f(u). Solved: trivial bounds u+2 ≤ f(u) ≤ u², with f(p) = p² for primes and f(n) = (1+o(1))n for almost all n.

title: Erdős Problem #464: Lacunary Sequences and Density of Fractional Parts
description: For lacunary A (n_{k+1} ≥ (1+ε)n_k), must there exist irrational θ with {‖θn_k‖} not dense? SOLVED: YES (de Mathan/Pollington 1979-80). Best bound: ε/log(1/ε) (Peres-Schlag 2010).

title: Erdős Problem #465: Points with Distances Avoiding Integers
description: Let N(X,δ) be the maximum number of points in a circle of radius X such that all pairwise distances avoid integers by at least δ. Is N(X,δ) = o(X)? Is N(X,δ) < X^{1/2+o(1)}? Both answered YES by Sárközy (1976) and Konyagin (2001).

title: Erdős Problem #470: Weird Numbers
description: A number n is called weird if σ(n) ≥ 2n (abundant) but n is not pseudoperfect (cannot be expressed as the sum of any subset of its proper divisors). Erdős asked two OPEN questions: (1) Are there any odd weird numbers? (2) Are there infinitely many primitive weird numbers?

title: Erdős Problem #471: Ulam's Prime Sequence Problem
description: Given a finite set of primes Q₀, define Qᵢ₊₁ = Qᵢ ∪ {primes that are sums of 3 distinct elements of Qᵢ}. Does there exist Q₀ such that Qᵢ becomes arbitrarily large?

title: Erdős Problem #473: Prime Sum Permutations
description: Is there a permutation a₁, a₂, ... of positive integers such that a_k + a_{k+1} is always prime? SOLVED: YES (Odlyzko). Related: greedy algorithm doesn't produce all primes as sums (197 missing).

title: Erdős Problem #474: Coloring ℝ² for Uncountable Sets
description: Under what set-theoretic assumptions can ℝ² be 3-colored such that every uncountable A has A² containing pairs of all colors? PARTIALLY RESOLVED: works under CH (Erdős), fails with large c (Shelah), open for c = ℵ₂.

title: Erdős Problem #475: Graham's Rearrangement Conjecture
description: Given A ⊆ 𝔽ₚ\{0}, does there exist an ordering with all partial sums distinct? Proven for t ≤ 12, t ≥ p-3, t ≤ exp((log p)^{1/4}). General case OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #476: The Erdős-Heilbronn Conjecture
description: For A ⊆ 𝔽ₚ, is |A +̂ A| ≥ min(2|A| - 3, p) where A +̂ A denotes sums of distinct pairs? YES, proved by da Silva-Hamidoune (1994).

title: Erdős Problem #479: Powers of 2 Modulo n
description: Is it true that, for all k ≠ 1, there are infinitely many n such that 2^n ≡ k (mod n)? This is Graham's conjecture.

title: Erdos Problem #48: Infinitely Many Pairs with phi(n) = sigma(m)
description: Are there infinitely many integers n, m such that phi(n) = sigma(m)? YES, proved by Ford-Luca-Pomerance (2010).

title: Erdős Problem #480: Sequence Approximation in the Unit Interval
description: For any sequence in [0,1], are there infinitely many pairs (m,n) with |x_{m+n} - x_m| ≤ 1/(√5·n)? Solved by Chung-Graham (1984) with optimal constant.

title: Erdős Problem #481: Affine Sequence Iteration and Eventual Repetition
description: For affine maps T with Σ(1/aᵢ) > 1, iterating from A₁=(1) must eventually produce repeated elements. Proved by Klarner (1982) using free semigroup theory.

title: Erdős Problem #482
description:
Forum
