Dual View
Random Solved
Random Open

Let ... be the maximal acyclic chromatic number of any graph with maximum degree ... - that is, the vertices of any graph wit...

title: Erdos Problem #798: Covering Lattice Points with Lines
description: What is the minimum number of points in {1,...,n}^2 needed to generate lines covering all lattice points? YES, t(n) = o(n); specifically t(n) = Theta(n^{2/3} log n).

title: Erdős Problem #799: List Chromatic Number of Random Graphs
description: Is the list chromatic number χ_L(G) = o(n) for almost all graphs on n vertices? YES, proved by Alon (1992) and refined by Alon-Krivelevich-Sudakov (1999).

title: Erdős Problem #8: Monochromatic Covering Systems
description: For any finite coloring of integers, must there exist a covering system with monochromatic moduli? DISPROVED by Hough (2015) using the minimum modulus bound.

title: Erdos Problem #80: Book Size in Triangle-Saturated Graphs
description: In dense graphs where every edge lies in a triangle, how large must the maximum 'book' be? Fox-Loh (2012) disproved polynomial growth; the precise rate for c < 1/4 remains OPEN.

title: Linear Ramsey Numbers for Graphs Without Adjacent High-Degree Vertices
description: If G is a graph on n vertices which has no two adjacent vertices of degree ≥ 3, then R(G) ≪ n, where R(G) is the Ramsey number and the implied constant is absolute. Solved by Noga Alon (1994) who proved R(G) ≤ 12n.

title: Erdős Problem #801: Dense Subgraphs in Graphs with Bounded Independence
description: If G is a graph on n vertices with no independent set larger than √n, then there exists a set of ≤ √n vertices containing ≫ √n log n edges. Proved by Alon (1996) using probabilistic methods.

title: Erdős Problem #802: Independent Sets in K_r-Free Graphs
description: Is it true that any K_r-free graph on n vertices with average degree t contains an independent set on (log t / t)n vertices? SOLVED for r=3 by AKS (1980). Partial progress for general r by Shearer (1995).

title: D-Balanced Subgraphs in Dense Graphs
description: Do graphs with n log n edges contain O(1)-balanced subgraphs with m log m edges? NO - disproved by Alon (2008). Maximum is O(m√(log m)).

title: Erdős Problem #804: Independent Sets in Locally Independent Graphs
description: If every induced subgraph on m vertices has independent set ≥ log n, how large must the global independent set be? The conjectured bounds n^(1/2-o(1)) and (log n)³ were DISPROVED by Alon-Sudakov (2007).

title: Erdős Problem #805: Large Cliques and Independent Sets in All Subgraphs
description: For which g(n) does there exist an n-vertex graph where every g(n)-subgraph has both a (log n)-clique and (log n)-independent set? PARTIALLY SOLVED: Bounds by Alon-Sudakov (2007) and Alon-Bucić-Sudakov (2021).

title: Erdős Problem #806: Small Bases for Sumsets
description: For A ⊆ {1,...,n} with |A| ≤ √n, must there exist B with |B| = o(√n) such that A ⊆ B + B? YES, with optimal bound Θ((log log n / log n) · √n).

title: Erdos Problem #807: Bipartite Decomposition of Random Graphs
description: Is the bipartition number of a random graph equal to n minus the independence number almost surely? NO, disproved by Alon (2015).

title: Graph-Restricted Sum-Product Bounds
description: Graph version of sum-product: with n^{1+c} edges, is max(|A+_G A|, |A·_G A|) ≥ n^{1+c-ε}? DISPROVED by Alon-Ruzsa-Solymosi (2020). Counterexample: n^{5/3} edges give only n^{4/3} outputs. Positive result: max ≥ m^{3/2}/n^{7/4}.

title: Rainbow Colorings of Odd Cycles
description: For k≥3, define F_k(n) = min r s.t. some graph on n vertices with ⌊n²/4⌋+1 edges can be r-colored with all C_{2k+1} rainbow. Conjecture: F_k(n) ~ n²/8. Known: F_k(n) ≫ n². OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #81: Clique Partitions of Chordal Graphs
description: Can every chordal graph (no induced cycles > 3) have its edges partitioned into n²/6 + O(n) cliques? The lower bound is achieved by specific constructions, but the upper bound remains open despite progress on split graphs.

title: Rainbow Graphs in Balanced Edge-Colorings
description: Characterize graphs G such that every balanced edge-coloring of K_n contains a rainbow copy of G. K_4 fails (Clemen-Wagner 2023), but full characterization is open.

title: Erdős Problem #812: Growth of Consecutive Ramsey Numbers
description: Two questions about Ramsey number growth: (1) Is R(n+1)/R(n) ≥ 1+c for some c > 0? (2) Is R(n+1) - R(n) ≫ n²? Both questions remain OPEN. Best known: R(n+1) - R(n) ≥ 4n - 8 (Burr-Erdős-Faudree-Schelp 1989).

title: Erdős Problem #813: Triangles in Every 7-Vertex Set
description: Let h(n) be minimal such that every graph on n vertices where every 7-vertex set contains a triangle must contain a clique of size h(n). Estimate h(n). OPEN with progress: n^{1/3} ≪ h(n) ≪ n^{1/2} (Erdős-Hajnal), improved to h(n) ≫ n^{5/12-o(1)} (Bucić-Sudakov 2023).

title: Erdős Problem #814: Dense Graphs Contain Smaller Min-Degree-k Subgraphs
description: For k ≥ 2, does every dense graph contain a small induced subgraph with minimum degree k? YES, proved by Sauermann (2019).

title: Erdős Problem #815: Cycles in Degree 3 Critical Graphs
description: Must degree 3 critical graphs (n vertices, 2n-2 edges, proper subgraphs have min degree ≤ 2) contain C_k for all k ≥ 3? DISPROVED by Narins-Pokrovskiy-Szabó (2017): arbitrarily large such graphs exist with no C_23.

title: Erdős Problem #816: Equal-Degree Vertices and Paths of Length 3
description: Let G be a graph with 2n+1 vertices and n² + n + 1 edges. Must G contain two vertices of the same degree joined by a path of length 3? YES - proved by Chen-Ma (2025).

title: Erdős Problem #817: Subset Sum Sets and Arithmetic Progressions
description: Given a set A ⊆ {1,...,N} of size n, the subset sum set ⟨A⟩ consists of all possible sums of subsets of A. How large must N be for ⟨A⟩ to avoid non-trivial 3-term arithmetic progressions? An open problem asking whether g₃(n) ≫ 3ⁿ.

title: Product Set Lower Bound for Small Sumsets
description: If |A+A| ≤ K|A| (small sumset), is |AA| ≥ |A|²/(log|A|)^C for some C? Answer: YES. Solymosi (2009) proved the stronger bound |AA| ≥ c·|A|²/log|A|.

title: Erdős Problem #819: Sumsets of √N-Sized Sets
description: Let f(N) be maximal such that there exists A ⊆ {1,...,N} with |A| = ⌊√N⌋ such that |(A+A) ∩ [1,N]| = f(N). Estimate f(N).

title: Erdős Problem #820: GCD of Exponential Sequences
description: Let H(n) = min{l : ∃k<l with gcd(k^n-1, l^n-1)=1}. Is H(n)=3 infinitely often?

title: Erdős Problem #821: Large Values of the Euler Phi Preimage Function
description: Let g(n) count m with φ(m)=n. For every ε>0, are there infinitely many n with g(n) > n^{1-ε}? OPEN: Best known is g(n) > n^{0.71568} (Lichtman 2022).

title: Erdős Problem #822: Positive Density of n + φ(n)
description: Does the set of integers expressible as n + φ(n) have positive lower density? Gabdullin, Iudelevich, and Luca proved this is true in 2024.

title: Erdős Problem #823: Equal Sum of Divisors with Arbitrary Ratio
description: Given α ≥ 1, does there exist a sequence of integers n_k, m_k such that σ(n_k) = σ(m_k) and n_k/m_k → α? Solved affirmatively by Pollack (2015).

title: Erdős Problem #824: Coprime Pairs with Equal Sum of Divisors
description: Let h(x) count coprime pairs (a, b) with σ(a) = σ(b). Is h(x) > x^{2-o(1)}? Known: h(x)/x → ∞ (Pollack-Pomerance 2016).

title: Erdős Problem #828: Totient Divisibility φ(n) | n + a
description: For any integer a, are there infinitely many n such that φ(n) divides n + a?

title: Erdős Problem #829: Representations as Sums of Two Cubes
description: Is 1_A * 1_A(n) << (log n)^{O(1)} where A is the set of cubes? OPEN. Known: Mordell (unbounded), Mahler (>>(log n)^{1/4}), Stewart (>>(log n)^{11/13}).

title: Erdős Problem #83: Complete Intersection Theorem
description: For 2n-subsets of [4n] with pairwise intersections ≥ 2, the maximum family size is ½(C(4n,2n) - C(2n,n)²). Proved by Ahlswede-Khachatrian (1997), winning the $500 Erdős prize.

title: Erdős Problem #830: Amicable Pairs
description: Are there infinitely many amicable pairs? Two numbers are amicable if each is the sum of the other's proper divisors, like 220 and 284.

title: Erdős Problem #831: Distinct Radii Circles Through Point Configurations
description: Let h(n) be maximal such that any n points in general position have at least h(n) circles of distinct radii through triples. Estimate h(n). This problem remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #832: Minimum Edges in Hypergraphs with Given Chromatic Number
description: For r-uniform hypergraphs with chromatic number k, must there be ≥ C((r-1)(k-1)+1, r) edges? NO for r ≥ 4 (Alon 1985). Steiner triples disprove r=3, k=3. Asymptotic: m(r,k) ~ c_r · k^r.

title: Erdős Problem #833: Vertex Degrees in 3-Chromatic Hypergraphs
description: Does there exist c > 0 such that every r-uniform 3-chromatic hypergraph has a vertex in at least (1+c)^r edges? SOLVED by Erdős-Lovász (1975): YES, with bound 2^{r-1}/(4r).

title: 3-Critical 3-Uniform Hypergraphs
description: Does there exist a 3-critical 3-uniform hypergraph in which every vertex has degree ≥ 7? The answer depends on the definition of '3-critical': NO for transversal-criticality (Li 2025 proved max is 6), YES for chromatic-criticality (explicit constructions exist).

title: Erdős Problem #835: Chromatic Number of Johnson Graphs
description: Does there exist k > 2 such that J(2k,k) has chromatic number k+1? SOLVED: NO for 3 ≤ k ≤ 8. The chromatic number exceeds k+1 in all verified cases.

title: Erdős Problem #836: Intersecting 3-Chromatic Hypergraphs
description: For r-uniform hypergraphs with chromatic number 3 where any two edges intersect: Must there be O(r²) vertices? Must two edges meet in ≫r vertices?

title: Erdős Problem #838: Convex Subsets of Point Sets
description: Let f(n) be maximal such that any n points in ℝ², with no three collinear, determine at least f(n) convex subsets. Does lim (log f(n))/(log n)² = c exist? OPEN: Bounds n^{c₁ log n} < f(n) < n^{c₂ log n} known (Erdős 1978).

title: Erdős Problem #84: Counting Cycle Sets
description: How many distinct 'cycle sets' can graphs on n vertices have? The count f(n) lies between 2^{n/2} and 2^{n-2}. Verstraëte proved f(n) = o(2^n), but the second part showing f(n)/2^{n/2} → ∞ remains open.

title: Quasi-Sidon Subsets
description: How large can a quasi-Sidon subset of {1,...,N} be? A set A is quasi-Sidon if |A+A| = (1+o(1))·C(|A|,2). Bounds: (2/√3)√N ≤ f(N) ≤ 1.86√N.

title: Erdős Problem #841: Minimal Interval for Square Product
description: Let t_n be minimal such that {n+1,...,n+t_n} contains a subset whose product with n is a perfect square. Selfridge proved t_n = P(n) when P(n) > √(2n)+1, and t_n ≤ O(√n) otherwise. Bui-Pratt-Zaharescu (2024) showed t_n follows P(n)'s distribution.

title: 3-Colorability of Triangle-Hamiltonian Graphs
description: Let G be a graph on 3n vertices formed by taking n vertex-disjoint triangles and adding a Hamiltonian cycle. Does G have chromatic number at most 3? Answer: YES (Fleischner-Stiebitz 1992).

title: Erdős Problem #843: Are the Squares Ramsey 2-Complete?
description: Are the squares Ramsey 2-complete? That is, in any 2-coloring of the squares, can every sufficiently large n be written as a monochromatic sum of distinct squares? Answer: YES (Conlon-Fox-Pham 2021).

title: Erdős Problem #844: Maximum Set with Non-Squarefree Products
description: Let A ⊆ {1,...,N} such that for all a,b ∈ A, ab is not squarefree. Is the maximum achieved by A = even numbers ∪ odd non-squarefree? Answer: YES (Weisenberg; Alexeev-Mixon-Sawin).

title: Erdős Problem #845: Sums of 3-Smooth Numbers with Bounded Ratio
description: For C > 0, does the set of integers expressible as sums of 3-smooth numbers b₁ < ... < bₜ with bₜ ≤ Cb₁ have density 0? Disproved: all integers have such representations with C = 6.

title: Erdos Problem #847: AP-Free Subsets and Finite Unions
description: If infinite A has the property that every n-subset contains an AP-free subset of size >= epsilon*n, must A be a finite union of AP-free sets? DISPROVED.

title: Erdős Problem #849: Binomial Coefficient Multiplicities
description: Is it true that for every integer t ≥ 1, there is some integer a such that C(n,k) = a (with 1 ≤ k ≤ n/2) has exactly t solutions? Related to Singmaster's Conjecture.

title: Erdős Problem #85: Minimum Degree for 4-Cycles
description: Is the minimum degree threshold f(n) for forcing a 4-cycle monotone? That is, is f(n+1) ≥ f(n) for all large n?

title: Erdős Problem #851: Density of Integers 2^k + n
description: Romanoff (1934) proved that integers of the form 2^k + p (p prime) have positive lower density. Erdős asked: for any ε > 0, is there r such that integers of form 2^k + n (n has ≤ r prime factors) have density ≥ 1 - ε? OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #855: The Second Hardy-Littlewood Conjecture
description: Is π(x+y) ≤ π(x) + π(y) for large x,y? LIKELY FALSE - incompatible with the prime k-tuples conjecture (Hensley-Richards 1973).

title: LCM-Free Sets and Logarithmic Density
description: Estimate f_k(N), the maximum harmonic sum of subsets of {1,...,N} with no k elements having uniform pairwise LCM. Status: OPEN. Bounds relate to sunflower conjecture.

title: Erdős Problem #857: The Weak Sunflower Problem
description: Let m(n,k) be minimal such that any collection of m subsets of {1,...,n} contains a k-sunflower. Estimate m(n,k) or give an asymptotic formula. Connected to the Sunflower Conjecture and cap set problem.

title: Erdős Problem #858: Avoiding Multiplicative Relations with Large Prime Factors
description: For A ⊆ {1,...,N} with no at=b where a,b ∈ A and smallest prime factor of t > a, estimate max (1/log N) Σ_{n∈A} 1/n. SOLVED: The maximum is o(1) as N → ∞, proved by Alexander (1966) and Erdős-Sárközi-Szemerédi (1968).

title: Erdős #859: Density of Divisor Sum Representations
description: Let dₜ be the density of n where t is a sum of distinct divisors. Is dₜ ~ c₁/(log t)^c₂? Known: 1/(log t)^c₃ < dₜ < 1/(log t)^c₄ (Erdős 1970).

title: Erdős Problem #86: C₄-Free Subgraphs of Hypercubes
description: Let f(n) = max edges in a C₄-free subgraph of the n-hypercube Qₙ. Conjecture: f(n) ≤ (1/2+o(1))·n·2^(n-1). Known: 1/2 < f(n)/(n·2^(n-1)) ≤ 0.60318. The gap remains OPEN ($100 prize).

title: Erdős Problem #860: Prime Covering Intervals
description: Estimate h(n), the minimum interval length such that any interval contains distinct multiples of the first π(n) primes. OPEN: Known bounds are (3-o(1))n < h(n) ≪ n^(3/2)/(log n)^(1/2), but exact asymptotics unknown.

title: Counting Sidon Sets
description: Let f(N) be the max Sidon subset size and A(N) the number of Sidon subsets of {1,...,N}. Is A(N)/2^{f(N)} → ∞? (Yes) Is A(N) = 2^{(1+o(1))f(N)}? (No)

title: Erdős Problem #862: Maximal Sidon Subsets
description: Let A₁(N) be the number of maximal Sidon subsets of {1,...,N}. Is A₁(N) < 2^{o(N^{1/2})}? Is A₁(N) > 2^{N^c} for some c > 0? SOLVED: A₁(N) ≥ 2^{(0.16+o(1))√N} by Saxton-Thomason (2015).

title: Erdős Problem #865: Pairwise Sums in Dense Sets
description: If A ⊆ {1,...,N} has size ≥ (5/8)N + C, must there exist distinct a,b,c ∈ A with a+b, a+c, b+c ∈ A? The threshold 5/8 is conjectured optimal. Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #866: Pairwise Sums Threshold
description: For k ≥ 3, define g_k(N) as the minimal threshold such that A ⊆ {1,...,2N} with |A| ≥ N + g_k(N) contains all pairwise sums of some b₁,...,b_k. Known: g₃=2, g₄≤2032, g₅≍log N, g₆≍√N. General bounds have gaps.

title: Erdos Problem #867: Consecutive Sum-Free Sets
description: Is it true that a set A with no consecutive subsequence sums in A has size at most N/2 + O(1)? NO - disproved by Freud (1993) and Coppersmith-Phillips (1996).

title: Erdős Problem #868: Additive Bases and Minimal Bases
description: If A is an additive basis of order 2 with f(n) → ∞, must A contain a minimal additive basis of order 2?

title: Erdős Problem #869: Minimal Additive Bases from Disjoint Bases
description: If A₁, A₂ are disjoint additive bases of order 2, must A₁ ∪ A₂ contain a minimal additive basis?

title: Erdős Problem #870: Minimal Additive Bases
description: For k ≥ 3, if A is an additive basis of order k with r(n) ≥ c log n for large n, must A contain a minimal basis of order k? Known for k = 2 (Erdős-Nathanson 1979). Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #871: Partitioning Additive Bases of Order 2
description: Can an additive basis A of order 2 with r_A(n) → ∞ be partitioned into two disjoint additive bases of order 2? DISPROVED by Daniel Larsen (2026).

title: Erdős Problem #872: Antichain Saturation Game
description: How long can a two-player game on divisibility antichains in {2,...,n} be guaranteed to last when one player maximizes and one minimizes game length?

title: Erdős Problem #873: LCM of Consecutive Sequence Terms
description: Can the count of k-tuples with small LCM be made subpolynomial by choosing k large enough? An open problem of Erdős and Szemerédi on multiplicative structure of sequences.

title: Erdős Problem #874: Admissible Sets and Subset Sum Disjointness
description: Is k(N) ~ 2√N where k(N) is the max size of A ⊆ {1,...,N} with disjoint subset sums S_r? PROVED by Deshouillers-Freiman (1999).

title: Erdős Problem #876: Sum-Free Sets and Gap Growth
description: For an infinite sum-free set A = {a₁ < a₂ < ⋯}, how small can gaps aₙ₊₁ - aₙ be? Graham showed n^{1+o(1)} is achievable; whether gaps < n is possible remains OPEN.

title: Counting Maximal Sum-Free Subsets
description: Let f_m(n) count maximal sum-free subsets A of {1,...,n}. Is f_m(n) = o(2^{n/2})? SOLVED: YES. Sharp bounds show f_m(n) = (C_n + o(1))2^{n/4} where C_n depends on n mod 4.

title: Erdős Problem #878: Unconventional Number Theoretic Functions
description: Study of f(n) = ∑ pᵢ^ℓᵢ and F(n) = max ∑ aᵢ over coprime decompositions. Questions about their growth, asymptotics, and the unusual behavior of H(x) = ∑ f(n)/n. Open problem.

title: Erdős Problem #879: Maximum Sum of Pairwise Coprime Sets
description: For admissible (pairwise coprime) sets S ⊆ {1,...,n}, is G(n) = max Σa close to H(n) = Σp + n·π(√n)? OPEN: Is G(n) > H(n) - n^{1+o(1)}? Known bounds: H(n) - n^{3/2} < G(n) < H(n).

title: Erdős Problem #88: Induced Subgraphs in Ramsey Graphs
description: In a graph with no large clique or independent set, can we find induced subgraphs with any desired edge count up to δn²? The Erdős-McKay conjecture was proved by Kwan, Sah, Sauermann, and Sawhney (2022), earning the $100 prize.

title: Erdős Problem #880: Gaps in Restricted Additive Bases
description: If A is an additive basis of order k, are gaps in the restricted sumset k×A (sums of distinct elements) bounded? Answer: YES for k=2 (gaps ≤ 2), NO for k≥3. Solved by Hegyvári-Hennecart-Plagne (2007).

title: Erdős Problem #881: Minimal Additive Bases and Order Increase
description: For a minimal additive basis of order k, must there exist an infinite subset whose removal yields a basis of order k+1?

title: Erdős Problem #882: Subset Sums Without Divisibility
description: What is the maximum size of A ⊆ {1,...,n} such that no two distinct non-empty subset sums divide each other? Answer: (1+o(1)) log₂ n.

title: Erdos Problem #883: Cycles in the Coprime Graph
description: For a large subset A of {1,...,n}, does the coprime graph G(A) contain all short odd cycles? Question 2 SOLVED by Sarkozy (1999).

title: Erdős Problem #885: Common Factor Difference Sets
description: For n ≥ 1, define D(n) = {|a - b| : n = ab}. For every k ≥ 1, do there exist integers N₁ < ... < Nₖ with |∩ᵢ D(Nᵢ)| ≥ k? Solved for k ≤ 4; OPEN for k ≥ 5.

title: Erdős Problem #886: Divisors Near the Square Root (Ruzsa's Conjecture)
description: For ε > 0, is the count of divisors of n in the interval (√n, √n + n^{1/2-ε}) bounded by O_ε(1)? An open problem about divisor clustering attributed to Ruzsa.

title: Erdős Problem #887: Divisors in Short Intervals Near √n
description: Is there an absolute constant K such that for every C > 0 and sufficiently large n, n has at most K divisors in (√n, √n + C·n^{1/4})? Status: OPEN (partial results for perfect squares).

title: Erdős Problem #888: Square Products with ad = bc Constraint
description: What is the size of the largest A ⊆ {1,...,n} such that if a ≤ b ≤ c ≤ d ∈ A and abcd is a perfect square, then ad = bc? The exact answer is OPEN, but bounds are SOLVED: Sárközy proved |A| = o(n), while the primes show |A| ≫ n/log n.

title: Erdős Problem #89: Distinct Distances in the Plane
description: Does every set of n distinct points in ℝ² determine ≫ n/√(log n) many distinct distances?

title: Erdős Problem #891: Prime Factors in Short Intervals
description: For k ≥ 2 and large n, must every interval [n, n + p₁···pₖ) contain an integer with more than k prime factors? OPEN, even for k = 2 (intervals of length 6).

title: Erdős Problem #894: Chromatic Numbers of Lacunary Cayley Graphs
description: For a lacunary sequence A with n_{k+1} ≥ (1+ε)n_k, does there exist a finite coloring of ℕ with no monochromatic a-b ∈ A? SOLVED: YES, using O(ε⁻¹ log(1/ε)) colors (Peres-Schlag 2010).

title: Erdős Problem #895: Independent Additive Triples
description: In a triangle-free graph on {1,...,n}, must there exist independent vertices a, b, a+b? Yes, for n ≥ 18! Solved by Ben Barber via SAT verification.

title: Erdős Problem #897: Additive Functions and Consecutive Differences
description: For an additive function f with unbounded growth on prime powers, must consecutive differences f(n+1) - f(n) also be unbounded when normalized by log(n)?

title: Erdős Problem #898: The Erdős-Mordell Inequality
description: For an interior point P of triangle ABC, if X, Y, Z are the feet of perpendiculars from P to the sides, then PA + PB + PC ≥ 2(PX + PY + PZ). Equality holds iff the triangle is equilateral and P is its center.

title: Erdős Problem #899: Growth of Difference Sets
description: If A ⊆ ℕ has zero density, must the difference set A - A grow much faster than A? Ruzsa proved yes in 1978.

title: Erdős Problem #9: Odd Integers Not of the Form p + 2^k + 2^l
description: Is the upper density of odd integers not expressible as p + 2^k + 2^l positive? OPEN problem. Pan (2011) proved N^{1-ε} growth but positive density remains unresolved.

title: Erdős Problem #900: Longest Path in Sparse Random Graphs
description: There exists a function f:(1/2,∞)→ℝ with f(c)→0 as c→1/2 and f(c)→1 as c→∞, such that G(n,cn) has whp a path of length ≥f(c)n. SOLVED by Ajtai-Komlós-Szemerédi (1981).

title: Erdős #901: Property B and Hypergraph Coloring
description: Find m(n) = minimum edges in an n-uniform hypergraph without Property B (not 2-colorable). Known: √(n/log n)·2^n ≪ m(n) ≪ n²·2^n.

title: Erdős #902: Tournament Domination
description: Let f(n) be minimal such that there is a tournament on f(n) vertices such that every set of n vertices is dominated. Known: f(1)=3, f(2)=7, f(3)=19. Bounds: n·2^n ≪ f(n) ≪ n²·2^n.

title: Erdős Problem #903: Block Designs and the de Bruijn-Erdős Gap
description: For n = p² + p + 1 with p a prime power, if a block design on n points has t > n blocks, then t ≥ n + p. Proved by Erdős-Fowler-Sós-Wilson (1985).

title: Erdős Problem #904: Triangles with High Degree Sum
description: If G is a graph with n vertices and more than n²/4 edges, then it contains a triangle on vertices x, y, z such that d(x) + d(y) + d(z) ≥ (3/2)n. This was conjectured by Bollobás and Erdős and proved by Edwards in 1978.

title: Edge-Triangle Multiplicity Above Turán
description: Every graph with n vertices and > n²/4 edges contains an edge which is in at least n/6 triangles. Proved by Edwards (unpublished) and Hadziivanov-Nikiforov (1979).

title: Erdős Problem #906: Dense Zeros of Derivative Subsequences
description: Is there a transcendental entire function f : ℂ → ℂ such that for any subsequence of derivatives, their zeros are dense? Erdős claimed solved but no proof is known.

title: Erdős Problem #907: Decomposition of Functions with Continuous Differences
description: If f(x+h) - f(x) is continuous for every h > 0, can f be decomposed as g + φ for continuous g and additive φ? Answer: YES, proved by de Bruijn (1951).

title: Erdős Problem #908: Functions with Measurable Differences
description: If f : ℝ → ℝ has measurable differences (f(x+h) - f(x) is measurable for all h > 0), can f be decomposed as f = g + h + r where g is continuous, h is additive, and r is rigid? SOLVED: YES (Laczkovich, 1980).

title: Erdős Problem #909: Dimension of Product Spaces
description: Is there a space S of dimension n such that S² also has dimension n? YES (Anderson-Keisler 1967). For all n ≥ 1, such separable metric spaces exist.

title: Erdős Problem #91: Non-Uniqueness of Minimal Distance Sets
description: Among n-point sets minimizing the number of distinct distances, must there be multiple non-similar configurations for large n? Known for small n (the regular pentagon is uniquely optimal for n=5), but open in general.

title: Erdős Problem #910: Connected Subsets of Euclidean Space
description: Does every connected set in ℝⁿ have a proper connected subset that isn't a point or homeomorphic to the whole? Does it have more than 2^ℵ₀ connected subsets? Both NO—Rudin (1958) constructed a counterexample under CH.

title: Erdős Problem #911: Size Ramsey Numbers of Dense Graphs
description: Does there exist a function f(x) with f(x)/x → ∞ such that for all sufficiently large C, if G has n vertices and at least Cn edges, then R̂(G) > f(C) · e(G)?

title: Distinct Exponents in Factorial Factorization
description: If n! = ∏ pᵢ^{kᵢ}, let h(n) count distinct exponents kᵢ. Prove h(n) ~ c·√(n/log n) for some c > 0. Known: h(n) ≍ √(n/log n). Conjectured: c = √(2π).

title: Erdős Problem #914: Hajnal-Szemerédi Theorem (Vertex-Disjoint Cliques)
description: Every graph on rm vertices with minimum degree ≥ m(r-1) contains m vertex-disjoint copies of K_r. SOLVED by Hajnal-Szemerédi (1970).

title: Erdős Problem #915: Disjoint Paths in Graphs
description: Must a graph with 1+n(m-1) vertices and 1+nC(m,2) edges contain two vertices connected by m disjoint paths? SOLVED: Vertex-disjoint FALSE for m ≥ 5 (Leonard, Mader). Edge-disjoint TRUE for all m (Mader 1973).

title: Erdős Problem #916: Graphs with Cycles and Triply Adjacent Vertices
description: Does every graph with n vertices and 2n-2 edges contain a cycle and another vertex adjacent to three vertices on the cycle? YES, proved by Thomassen (1974).

title: Erdős Problem #917: Critical Graphs and Edge Density
description: Let k ≥ 4 and f_k(n) be the maximum edges in a k-critical graph on n vertices. Is f_k(n) ≫_k n²? Is f_6(n) ~ n²/4? For k ≥ 6, is f_k(n) ~ (1/2)(1 - 1/⌊k/3⌋)n²? PARTIALLY SOLVED: Question 1 YES (Toft 1970). Question 3 FALSE for k ≢ 0 (mod 3) (Stiebitz 1987).

title: Erdős Problem #918: Chromatic Numbers of Infinite Graphs
description: Two questions about graphs with large chromatic numbers: Can we have ℵ₂-chromatic graphs where all ℵ₁-subgraphs are countably chromatic? The main questions are OPEN, but Erdős-Hajnal proved the finite case.

title: Erdős Problem #919: Chromatic Numbers on Ordinal Products
description: Is there a graph G on vertex set ω₂² with chromatic number ℵ₂ such that every subgraph of smaller order type has chromatic number at most ℵ₀?

title: Erdős Problem #92: Equidistant Points in the Plane
description: Is f(n) ≤ n^{o(1)}, where f(n) is the maximum k such that some n-point set has k equidistant points from every point?

title: Erdős Problem #920: Chromatic Numbers of K_k-Free Graphs
description: Let g_k(n) denote the largest chromatic number of a K_k-free graph on n vertices. Is g_k(n) ≫ n^{1-1/(k-1)} / (log n)^c for k ≥ 4? This connects chromatic numbers to Ramsey theory.

title: Erdős Problem #921: Chromatic Number and Odd Cycle Girth
description: For k ≥ 4, let f_k(n) be the largest m such that there exists an n-vertex graph with χ = k where all odd cycles have length > m. SOLVED: f_k(n) ≍ n^{1/(k-2)} by Kierstead-Szemerédi-Trotter (1984).

title: Erdős Problem #922: Folkman's Chromatic Number Bound
description: If every subgraph H of a graph G contains an independent set of size at least (n-k)/2, must G have chromatic number at most k+2? Answer: YES, proved by Folkman (1970).

title: Triangle-Free Subgraphs with High Chromatic Number
description: For every k, is there f(k) such that graphs with chromatic number ≥ f(k) contain triangle-free subgraphs with chromatic number ≥ k? Answer: YES (Rödl, 1977).

title: Erdős Problem #924: Folkman-Nešetřil-Rödl Theorem (Ramsey without Large Cliques)
description: For k ≥ 2 and l ≥ 3, does there exist a K_{l+1}-free graph G such that every k-coloring of G's edges contains monochromatic K_l? SOLVED: YES by Folkman (1970, k=2) and Nešetřil-Rödl (1976, general).

title: Erdős Problem #925: Independent Sets in Non-Ramsey Graphs
description: Is there δ > 0 such that non-Ramsey graphs for K₃ on n vertices have independent sets of size ≫ n^(1/3+δ)? NO (Alon-Rödl 2005).

title: Erdős Problem #926: Turán Number of H_k
description: For k ≥ 4, is it true that ex(n; H_k) ≪_k n^(3/2), where H_k is the graph with central vertex x adjacent to k vertices y_1,...,y_k, and (k choose 2) vertices z_ij each adjacent to a unique pair y_i, y_j? Answer: YES. Proved by Füredi (1991) with bound (kn)^(3/2), improved by Alon-Krivelevich-Sudakov (2003) to k·n^(3/2).

title: Erdős Problem #927: Distinct Clique Sizes in Graphs
description: Let g(n) be the maximum number of distinct clique sizes in a graph on n vertices. Is g(n) = n - log₂n - log*(n) + O(1)? Answer: NO.

title: Erdős Problem #928: Density of Consecutive Smooth Numbers
description: Does the natural density of n with P(n) < n^α and P(n+1) < (n+1)^β exist? Logarithmic density = ρ(1/α)ρ(1/β) (Teräväinen 2018). Natural density conditional on Elliott-Halberstam (Wang 2021). OPEN unconditionally.

title: Erdős Problem #93: Distinct Distances in Convex Polygons
description: The vertices of a convex n-gon determine at least ⌊n/2⌋ distinct distances. Proved by Altman (1963), this is a foundational result in discrete geometry, though stronger variants remain open.

title: Erdős Problem #930: Products of Disjoint Intervals and Perfect Powers
description: Is it true that, for every r, there is a k such that if I₁,...,Iᵣ are disjoint intervals of consecutive integers, all of length at least k, then their combined product is not a perfect power?

title: Erdős Problem #932: Smooth Numbers in Prime Gaps
description: For infinitely many r, are there at least two integers in the prime gap (p_r, p_{r+1}) whose prime factors are all smaller than the gap size p_{r+1} - p_r?

title: Erdős Problem #933: Smooth Part of Consecutive Products
description: For n(n+1) = 2^k · 3^l · m with gcd(m,6)=1, is limsup 2^k 3^l / (n log n) = ∞? SOLVED: YES. Steinerberger's proof uses n = 2^{3^r}.

title: Erdős Problem #934: Edge Distance in Bounded-Degree Graphs
description: Let h_t(d) be minimal such that every graph with h_t(d) edges and max degree ≤ d contains two edges at distance ≥ t. Solved for t=1,2; partial for t=3; general bounds known.

title: Erdős Problem #936: Powerful Numbers Near 2^n and n!
description: Are 2^n ± 1 and n! ± 1 powerful for only finitely many n? Conditionally YES assuming the ABC conjecture (Cushing-Pascoe 2016, CrowdMath 2020).

title: Erdős Problem #937: Arithmetic Progressions of Coprime Powerful Numbers
description: Are there infinitely many four-term arithmetic progressions of pairwise coprime powerful numbers? YES, proved by Bajpai-Bennett-Chan (2024).

title: Erdős Problem #938: Three-term Progressions in Consecutive Powerful Numbers
description: Are there only finitely many three-term arithmetic progressions among consecutive powerful numbers?

title: Erdős Problem #939: r-Powerful Numbers and Sums
description: If r ≥ 4, can the sum of r-2 coprime r-powerful numbers ever be itself r-powerful? A number is r-powerful if every prime factor appears with exponent at least r.

title: Erdős #94: Distance Multiplicities in Convex Polygons
description: For n points forming a convex polygon with distance multiplicities f(u), prove ∑ f(u)² = O(n³). Solved by Fishburn, strengthened by Lefmann-Theile.

title: Erdős #940: Sums of r-Powerful Numbers
description: For r ≥ 3, does the set of integers expressible as sums of at most r r-powerful numbers have density 0? Partial results by Baker-Brüdern (1994) and Heath-Brown (1988).

title: Erdős Problem #941: Sums of Three Powerful Numbers
description: Are all large integers the sum of at most three powerful numbers (p | n → p² | n)? SOLVED: YES (Heath-Brown 1988). Every sufficiently large integer is the sum of at most 3 powerful numbers.

title: Erdős Problem #942: Powerful Numbers Between Consecutive Squares
description: Let h(n) count the powerful (squarefull) integers in [n², (n+1)²). Is there a constant c > 0 such that h(n) ~ (log n)^c? Known: limsup h(n) = ∞, densities δ_l exist with Σδ_l = 1, and h(n) ≥ c(log n/log log n)^{1/3} infinitely often (De Koninck-Luca 2004). The precise growth rate remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #944: Critical Graphs Without Critical Edges
description: For k ≥ 4 and r ≥ 1, does there exist a k-vertex-critical graph where every critical edge set has size > r? The case k = 4 remains OPEN; all k ≥ 5 are solved.

title: Erdős Problem #945: Consecutive Integers with Distinct Divisor Counts
description: How long can a run of consecutive integers be where all have distinct numbers of divisors? Is the maximum length bounded by a polynomial in log x?

title: Erdős Problem #946: Consecutive Integers with Equal Divisor Count
description: Are there infinitely many n with τ(n) = τ(n+1)? Heath-Brown proved yes in 1984, with quantitative bounds by Hildebrand and Erdős-Pomerance-Sárközy.

title: No Exact Covering Systems Exist
description: There is no exact covering system with distinct moduli - no finite collection of congruence classes aᵢ (mod nᵢ) with distinct nᵢ can partition ℤ exactly. Proved independently by Mirsky-Newman and Davenport-Rado.

title: Erdős Problem #948: Subset Sums and Colorings
description: Does there exist f(n) and k such that for any k-coloring, there is a sequence a with aₙ < f(n) infinitely often, whose subsums don't contain all colors?

title: Erdős Problem #95: Sum of Squared Distance Multiplicities
description: For n points in ℝ² with distance multiplicities f(uᵢ), prove ∑f(uᵢ)² ≪ n^{3+ε}. Solved by Guth and Katz (2015) with the stronger bound n³ log n, as part of their landmark distinct distances paper.

title: Erdős Problem #950: Sum of Reciprocal Prime Gaps
description: Study the behavior of f(n) = ∑_{p<n} 1/(n-p), the sum of reciprocals of distances to primes.

title: Erdős Problem #951: Beurling Prime Numbers
description: Is it true that #{aᵢ ≤ x} ≤ π(x) for any Beurling prime sequence? Are the primes the densest well-separated sequence?

title: Erdős Problem #952: The Gaussian Moat Problem
description: Is there an infinite sequence of distinct Gaussian primes x₁, x₂, ... with bounded gaps |x_{n+1} - xₙ| ≪ 1?

title: Erdős Problem #953: Avoiding Integer Distances in the Plane
description: What is the maximum measure of a set A ⊆ B(0,r) that avoids integer distances between its points?

title: Erdős Problem #955: Sum of Proper Divisors and Density
description: If A ⊂ ℕ has density 0, must s⁻¹(A) also have density 0, where s(n) is the sum of proper divisors? Proved for primes (Pollack), sums of two squares (Troupe), and sparse sets (PPT). General case OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #956: Unit Distances Between Convex Translates
description: Let h(n) be the max unit distances among n disjoint convex translates. Is h(n) > n^(1+c) for some c > 0? OPEN: Known bounds are Ω(n log n / log log n) ≤ h(n) ≤ O(n^(4/3)).

title: Erdos Problem #957: Product of Extreme Distance Frequencies
description: For n points in the plane with distances {d_1 < ... < d_k} and f(d) = frequency of distance d, is f(d_1)f(d_k) <= (9/8 + o(1))n^2? YES (Dumitrescu 2019).

title: Erdős Problem #958: Distance Multiplicities and Point Configurations
description: Is it true that k = n-1 distinct distances with multiplicities {n-1,...,1} characterizes equidistant points on a line or circle? NO - other configurations exist (Clemen-Dumitrescu-Liu, 2025).

title: Unit Distances in Convex Polygons
description: In a convex n-gon, are there only O(n) pairs at unit distance? Conjectured by Erdős-Moser. Best upper: n log n (Aggarwal 2015), lower: 2n-7 (Edelsbrunner-Hajnal 1991). OPEN.

title: Erdős #961: Smooth Numbers in Consecutive Intervals
description: Let f(k) = minimal n such that any n consecutive integers > k contain a number with a prime factor > k. Bounds known; polylogarithmic conjecture is open.

title: Consecutive Integers with Large Prime Divisors
description: Let k(n) be the maximal k such that there exists m ≤ n where each of m+1,...,m+k is divisible by at least one prime > k. Estimate k(n). Known bounds: exp(c√(log n log log n)) ≤ k(n) ≤ (1+o(1))√n.

title: Erdős Problem #964: Divisor Function Ratios
description: Is {τ(n+1)/τ(n) : n ≥ 1} dense in (0, ∞)? YES - Eberhard (2025) proved all positive rationals appear as such ratios.

title: Erdős Problem #965: Monochromatic Sums in 2-Colorings of ℝ
description: Is it true that for any 2-coloring of ℝ, there exists an uncountable set A with cardinality ℵ₁ such that all pairwise sums a+b are monochromatic? Answer: NO (Erdős 1975, Komjáth 2016).

title: Erdős Problem #966: Ramsey-Type Arithmetic Progressions
description: For k, r ≥ 2, does there exist a set A ⊆ ℕ with no (k+1)-term arithmetic progression, yet every r-coloring has a monochromatic k-term AP? YES, proved by Spencer (~1975).

title: Erdős Problem #967: Zeros of Generalized Dirichlet Sums
description: For integers 1 < a₁ < a₂ < ... with ∑(1/aᵢ) < ∞, is 1 + ∑ₖ 1/aₖ^(1+it) ≠ 0 for all t ∈ ℝ? Answer: NO - disproved by Yip (2025).

title: Erdős Problem #968: Normalized Prime Sequence
description: For uₙ = pₙ/n (normalized n-th prime), does the set of n where uₙ < uₙ₊₁ have positive density? Erdős-Prachar proved decreasing steps have positive density.

title: Erdős Problem #969: Error Term in Squarefree Integer Counting
description: Determine the order of magnitude of the error term E(x) in the asymptotic Q(x) = (6/π²)x + E(x), where Q(x) counts squarefree integers up to x.

title: Erdős Problem #97: Equidistant Vertices in Convex Polygons
description: Does every convex polygon have a vertex with no other 4 vertices equidistant from it?

title: Erdős Problem #970: Jacobsthal's Function
description: Is h(k) = O(k²) where h(k) is the minimal m such that any m consecutive integers contain one coprime to any n with at most k prime factors? OPEN: Best upper bound is (k log k)² by Iwaniec (1978).

title: Erdős Problem #971: Distribution of Least Primes in Arithmetic Progressions
description: For p(a,d) the least prime congruent to a mod d, does there exist c > 0 such that p(a,d) > (1+c)φ(d)log d for many residue classes a, for all large d?

title: Erdős Problem #972: Primes p with Floor(pα) Also Prime
description: For irrational α > 1, are there infinitely many primes p such that floor(pα) is also prime? An open problem of Erdős involving prime distribution under irrational scaling.

title: Erdős Problem #973: Power Sums of Complex Numbers
description: Does there exist C > 1 such that max|∑z_i^k| < C^{-n} for sequences with |z_i| ≥ 1? SOLVED: Depends on constraint. C ≈ 1.32 (disk), C ≈ 1.7455 (circle), Turán bound (outside).

title: Erdős Problem #974: Power Sums and Roots of Unity
description: If power sums sₖ = Σ zᵢᵏ have infinitely many (n-1)-tuples of consecutive zeros, then the zᵢ are essentially nth roots of unity. Proved by Tijdeman (1966) in a stronger form.

title: Erdős Problem #975: Divisor Sums over Polynomial Values
description: Does the sum of divisor counts over polynomial values have an asymptotic formula with a specific constant?

title: Erdős Problem #976: Greatest Prime Divisor of Polynomial Products
description: For an irreducible polynomial f ∈ ℤ[x] of degree d ≥ 2, what is the growth rate of F_f(n) = greatest prime divisor of ∏_{m=1}^n f(m)? The main conjectures (n^{1+c} or n^d growth) remain OPEN, though Tenenbaum (1990) proved F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c).

title: Erdős #977: Greatest Prime Factor of 2^n - 1
description: Does P(2^n - 1)/n → ∞? Solved by Stewart (2013): P(2^n - 1) ≥ n^{1 + 1/(104 log log n)}. Schinzel (1962) proved P(2^n - 1) > 2n for n > 12.

title: Erdős Problem #978: Power-Free Values of Polynomials
description: For irreducible polynomial f of degree d: (1) (d-1)-power-free values have positive density - YES (Hooley 1967). (2) Infinitely many (d-2)-power-free - YES for d≥9 (Browning 2011). (3) n⁴+2 squarefree - OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #979: Sums of k-th Powers of Primes
description: For k primes p_1,...,p_k, count solutions to n = p_1^k + ... + p_k^k. Is this count unbounded? Erdős proved YES for k=2,3; k>=4 remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #980: Sum of Least k-th Power Nonresidues
description: For k ≥ 2, let n_k(p) denote the least k-th power nonresidue modulo prime p. Is it true that Σ_{p<x} n_k(p) ~ c_k · x/log x for some constant c_k > 0? SOLVED: Yes, proved by Erdős (1961) for k=2 and Elliott (1967) for all k ≥ 2.

title: Erdős Problem #981: Character Sum Stabilization Threshold
description: For ε > 0, let f_ε(p) be the smallest m such that |∑_{n≤N}(n/p)| < εN for all N ≥ m. Elliott (1969) proved ∑_{p<x} f_ε(p) ~ c_ε · x/log x.

title: Erdos Problem #982: Distinct Distances from Convex Polygon Vertices
description: If n distinct points in the plane form a convex polygon, then some vertex has at least floor(n/2) different distances to other vertices.

title: Erdős Problem #983: Prime Coverage Function for Smooth Numbers
description: Does 2π(√n) - f(π(n)+1, n) → ∞? Answer: NO. Erdős-Straus (1970) showed f(π(n)+1, n) = 2π(√n) + o(√n/(log n)^A).

title: Erdős Problem #984: 2-Coloring with Controlled Monochromatic Progressions
description: Can ℕ be 2-colored such that any k-term monochromatic arithmetic progression starting at a satisfies k ≪_ε a^ε for all ε > 0? Zach Hunter proved YES, improving on Spencer's 3-color result and Erdős's partial k ≪ a^{1-c} bound.

title: Erdős Problem #985: Prime Primitive Roots
description: Is it true that for every prime p, there is a prime q < p which is a primitive root modulo p?

title: Erdős Problem #986: Ramsey Number Lower Bounds
description: For fixed k ≥ 3, is R(k,n) ≫ n^(k-1)/(log n)^c? YES for k=3 (Spencer 1977), YES for k=4 (Mattheus-Verstraete 2023), OPEN for k≥5. Gap between known bounds grows with k.

title: Erdős Problem #987: Exponential Sums and Sequence Discrepancy
description: For sequence x₁,x₂,... ∈ (0,1) and Aₖ = limsup|∑e(kxⱼ)|, is limsup Aₖ = ∞? Is Aₖ = o(k) possible? PARTIALLY OPEN: Proved Aₖ ≫ √k infinitely often; question of o(k) remains open.

title: Erdős Problem #988: Discrepancy on the Sphere
description: Does the minimum discrepancy of n-point configurations on the sphere tend to infinity? YES, proved by Schmidt (1969). For S²: n^{1/3} ≤ min D(n) ≤ n^{1/2}.

title: Erdős Problem #989: Circle Discrepancy
description: For an infinite sequence A ⊂ ℝ², define f(r) = max_C |#(A∩C) - πr²| over circles of radius r. Beck (1987) proved f(r) ≫ r^{1/2} for all A (lower bound), and ∃A with f(r) ≪ (r log r)^{1/2} (upper bound). The optimal growth is Θ̃(√r).

title: Erdős Problem #99: Equilateral Triangles in Minimal Diameter Sets
description: Must n points with min distance 1 and minimal diameter contain a unit equilateral triangle for large n? Erdős offered $100 for a counterexample but only $50 for a proof. The problem remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #990: Polynomial Root Distribution and the Erdős-Turán Inequality
description: For a complex polynomial f with d roots having arguments θ₁,...,θ_d, is the discrepancy |#{θᵢ ∈ I} - |I|d/(2π)| bounded by O(√(n log M)) where n is the sparsity? Classical Erdős-Turán (1950) proved this with d, the sparse case remains OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #991: Discrepancy of Optimal Logarithmic Energy Points
description: Do optimal logarithmic energy point configurations on S² have small spherical cap discrepancy? YES, proved via classical potential theory with quantitative bounds by Brauchart (2008) and Marzo-Mas (2021).

title: Erdős Problem #992: Discrepancy of Sequences mod 1
description: For integer sequence x₁ < x₂ < ⋯, is D(N) ≪ √N·(log N)^{o(1)} for almost all α? Known: D(N) ≪ √N·(log N)^{3/2} (Baker 1981). Status: OPEN.

title: Erdős Problem #993: Unimodal Independent Set Sequences in Trees
description: Is the independent set sequence of any tree or forest unimodal? YES! If i_k(T) counts independent sets of size k, the sequence i_0, i_1, i_2, ... increases then decreases. Contrasts with general graphs where any pattern is achievable.

title: Erdős Problem #994: Khintchine's Equidistribution Conjecture
description: For almost all α, is lim (1/n)∑1_{kα∈E} = λ(E) for ALL measurable E ⊆ (0,1)? DISPROVED: Marstrand (1970) showed this is FALSE. The quantifiers cannot be exchanged.

title: Erdős Problem #995: Lacunary Sequences and Fractional Parts
description: Estimate growth of ∑_{k≤N} f({α n_k}) for lacunary sequences. Is it o(N √(log log N))? Status: OPEN. Bounds: (log log N)^{1/2-ε} ≤ growth ≤ (log N)^{1/2+ε}.

title: Erdős #996: Strong Law for Lacunary Sequences
description: For lacunary sequences and L² functions, if ‖f - fₙ‖₂ = O(1/(log log log n)^C), does the strong law hold? Open. Known: log log decay with c > 1/2 suffices (Matsuyama 1966).

title: Erdős Problem #997: Well-Distributed Sequences and Primes
description: Is it true that for every α, the sequence {αpₙ} of fractional parts of prime multiples is not well-distributed? The 2024 result by Champagne-Le-Liu-Wooley shows this holds for at least one irrational α.

title: Erdős Problem #998: Kesten's Equidistribution Characterization
description: For irrational α, intervals [u,v) with O(1) discrepancy in #{m ≤ n : {αm} ∈ [u,v)} are exactly those where u = {αk} and v = {αℓ}. Solved by Kesten (1966).

title: Erdős Problem #999: The Duffin-Schaeffer Conjecture
description: For any f: ℕ → ℕ, almost all α have infinitely many coprime approximations |α - p/q| < f(q)/q iff ∑ φ(q)·f(q)/q = ∞. SOLVED by Koukoulopoulos-Maynard (2020) after 79 years!

title: Erdős–Szekeres Theorem
description: Any sequence of at least (r-1)(s-1) + 1 distinct numbers contains either an increasing subsequence of length r, or a decreasing subsequence of length s.

title: Euler's Identity
description: The most beautiful equation in mathematics: e^(iπ) + 1 = 0. This elegant identity connects five fundamental constants—e, i, π, 1, and 0—in one perfect equation.

title: Euler's Polyhedral Formula
description: For any convex polyhedron: V - E + F = 2, where V = vertices, E = edges, F = faces. This is the Euler characteristic of a sphere.

title: Euler's Generalization of Fermat's Little Theorem
description: For coprime integers a and n, a^φ(n) ≡ 1 (mod n), where φ(n) is Euler's totient function. This generalizes Fermat's Little Theorem.

title: Factor and Remainder Theorems
description: Two fundamental theorems connecting polynomial division, roots, and evaluation: (x - a) divides p(x) iff p(a) = 0 (Factor Theorem), and the remainder when dividing p(x) by (x - a) equals p(a) (Remainder Theorem).

title: The Fair Games Theorem
description: In a fair game (expected gain is zero), a gambler with finite wealth playing against an infinitely wealthy opponent will eventually go bankrupt with probability 1.

title: Fermat's Sum of Two Squares
description: A prime p can be expressed as a sum of two squares if and only if p = 2 or p is congruent to 1 (mod 4). Formalized using Zagier's elegant one-sentence proof.

title: Fermat's Last Theorem
description: Andrew Wiles' monumental proof that there are no three positive integers a, b, c such that a^n + b^n = c^n for any integer n > 2, resolving a 358-year-old conjecture through the modularity of elliptic curves.

title: Feuerbach's Theorem
description: The nine-point circle of a triangle is tangent to its incircle and all three excircles. A beautiful result in triangle geometry.

title: Four Color Theorem
description: Every planar map can be colored with at most four colors such that no adjacent regions share a color. First major theorem proved by computer (1976), the proof sparked debates about the nature of mathematical truth.

title: Fourier Series
description: Every periodic function can be represented as an infinite sum of sines and cosines (Fourier series). A cornerstone of analysis with applications throughout science.

title: Friendship Theorem
description: The Friendship Theorem (Erdős–Rényi–Sós, 1966): In any finite graph where every pair of distinct vertices has exactly one common neighbor, there exists a 'politician' vertex adjacent to all others.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
description: Every integer > 1 is uniquely representable as a product of primes. The cornerstone of number theory.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
description: Every non-constant polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root. This profound theorem reveals that the complex numbers are algebraically closed - they contain all solutions to polynomial equations.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
description: The profound connection between differentiation and integration: Newton and Leibniz's crowning achievement that unified the two pillars of calculus into a single coherent theory.

title: Greatest Common Divisor Algorithm
description: The Euclidean algorithm correctly computes the GCD: gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, a mod b). One of the oldest algorithms still in use, dating back to Euclid's Elements (c. 300 BCE).

title: Gelfond-Schneider Theorem
description: If a and b are algebraic numbers with a not equal to 0, 1 and b irrational, then a^b is transcendental. Resolves Hilbert's 7th Problem.

title: Solution of the General Quartic
description: Ferrari's method for solving quartic equations using a resolvent cubic. Every quartic x^4 + ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d = 0 can be solved by radicals.

title: Sum of a Geometric Series
description: The classic formulas for finite and infinite geometric series: for |r| < 1, the infinite sum converges to 1/(1-r).

title: Gödel's First Incompleteness Theorem
description: Any consistent formal system capable of expressing basic arithmetic contains statements that are true but unprovable within the system. This 1931 theorem shattered Hilbert's program and revealed fundamental limits of formal reasoning.

title: Green's Theorem
description: Green's theorem relates a line integral around a closed curve to a double integral over the enclosed region, connecting circulation to curl.

title: Undecidability of the Halting Problem
description: Turing's 1936 proof that no algorithm can determine whether an arbitrary program halts, establishing fundamental limits on computation using the diagonal argument.

title: Divergence of the Harmonic Series
description: The harmonic series 1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + ... diverges, despite its terms approaching zero. A classic result with an elegant 14th-century proof.

title: The Hermite-Lindemann Theorem
description: For any non-zero algebraic number alpha, e^alpha is transcendental. This implies the transcendence of both e and pi.

title: Heron's Formula
description: Area = √(s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)) where s is the semi-perimeter. Computes triangle area from side lengths alone.

title: Hilbert's Tenth Problem: Undecidability of Diophantine Equations
description: The MRDP theorem (1970) proves that no algorithm can determine whether an arbitrary Diophantine equation has integer solutions, answering Hilbert's 1900 challenge in the negative.

title: Hilbert's 11th Problem: Quadratic Forms
description: Classification of quadratic forms over number fields. The Hasse-Minkowski theorem provides a local-global principle for rational solutions.

title: Hilbert's 13th Problem: Superposition of Functions
description: The Kolmogorov-Arnold theorem (1956-57) disproves Hilbert's conjecture: every continuous function of n variables can be represented using functions of only one variable.

title: Hilbert's Fourteenth Problem: Finiteness of Invariant Systems
description: Hilbert's 14th problem asked whether the ring of invariants is always finitely generated. Nagata (1959) showed the answer is NO in general, but Hilbert-Mumford proved YES for reductive groups.

title: Hilbert's 15th Problem: Schubert Calculus
description: Rigorous foundation of Schubert's enumerative calculus for counting geometric configurations in Grassmannians.

title: Hilbert's 16th Problem: Limit Cycles
description: The maximum number of limit cycles for polynomial vector fields remains one of the most notorious open problems in mathematics.

title: Hilbert's 17th Problem: Sum of Squares
description: Artin's theorem: every non-negative polynomial is a sum of squares of rational functions, but not necessarily polynomials (Motzkin's counterexample).

title: Hilbert's Nineteenth Problem: Regularity of Variational Solutions
description: Hilbert's 1900 question on whether variational minimizers are analytic was resolved affirmatively by De Giorgi (1957) and Nash (1958): solutions of uniformly elliptic PDEs with smooth data are smooth.

title: Hilbert's Twentieth Problem: Boundary Value Problems
description: Hilbert's 1900 question about the solvability of boundary value problems was resolved through Lax-Milgram (1954) for elliptic PDEs, but Lewy's example (1957) showed some smooth PDEs have no solutions.

title: Hilbert's 21st Problem: Riemann-Hilbert Problem
description: The Riemann-Hilbert problem asks whether a Fuchsian system exists with given singularities and monodromy. The answer is YES for irreducible representations (Plemelj, 1908), but NO in general (Bolibrukh, 1989).

title: Hilbert's Twenty-Second Problem: Uniformization Theorem
description: The Uniformization Theorem (Koebe-Poincare, 1907) proves that every simply connected Riemann surface is conformally equivalent to the Riemann sphere, the complex plane, or the unit disk, completely solving Hilbert's call for uniformization by automorphic functions.

title: Hilbert's Twenty-Third Problem: Calculus of Variations
description: Hilbert's 1900 call for further development of the calculus of variations has been spectacularly answered through direct methods (Tonelli), weak solutions (Sobolev), optimal control (Pontryagin), and geometric measure theory.

title: Hilbert's 3rd Problem: Scissors Congruence
description: The Dehn invariant proves that a cube and regular tetrahedron of equal volume are NOT scissors congruent, answering Hilbert's 3rd Problem.

title: Hilbert's 4th Problem: Straight Line as Shortest Distance
description: Busemann's characterization of projective metrics where straight lines are geodesics, including Minkowski and Hilbert geometries.

title: Hilbert's 5th Problem: Lie Groups Without Differentiability
description: Are continuous groups automatically differential groups? The Montgomery-Zippin theorem (1952) shows that locally Euclidean topological groups are Lie groups.

title: Hilbert's Sixth Problem: Axiomatization of Physics
description: Hilbert's 1900 call for rigorous axiomatization of physics has been partially achieved through Kolmogorov's probability axioms (1933), von Neumann's quantum mechanics (1932), and other foundational frameworks.

title: Hilbert's Ninth Problem: The Most General Reciprocity Law
description: Hilbert's 9th problem asked for the most general reciprocity law in algebraic number fields. The answer is Artin reciprocity (1927), which unifies quadratic, cubic, and all higher reciprocity laws through class field theory.

title: The Hodge Conjecture
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Every Hodge class on a projective variety is a rational combination of algebraic cycle classes.

title: Hurwitz's Theorem
description: There are only four n-square identities: for n = 1, 2, 4, 8. This profound constraint explains why only the reals, complex numbers, quaternions, and octonions can be normed division algebras. Includes a complete proof that n=3 is impossible.

title: Principle of Inclusion/Exclusion
description: The fundamental counting principle for unions of finite sets: |A ∪ B| = |A| + |B| - |A ∩ B|, and its generalization to three or more sets.

title: Infinitude of Prime Numbers
description: Euclid's elegant proof that there are infinitely many prime numbers, formalized in Lean 4 with Mathlib.

title: Intermediate Value Theorem
description: A continuous function on a closed interval attains every value between its endpoints: the foundational theorem connecting topology to analysis.

title: The Isoperimetric Theorem
description: Among all curves of a given perimeter, the circle encloses the maximum area. Equivalently, among all shapes of a given area, the circle has minimum perimeter.

title: Isosceles Triangle Theorem
description: In an isosceles triangle, the base angles are equal. Known as Pons Asinorum (Bridge of Asses).

title: Kepler Conjecture: Sphere Packing
description: The face-centered cubic lattice achieves the maximum sphere packing density of pi/(3*sqrt(2)). Part of Hilbert's 18th Problem, proven by Hales (1998).

title: Knight's Tour Oblique Angles
description: Every closed knight's tour has at least 4 oblique (>90 degree) turns, and exactly one tour achieves this minimum. Based on Donald Knuth's 2025 Christmas Lecture.

title: Königsberg Bridges Problem
description: Euler's 1736 proof that it's impossible to walk through Königsberg crossing each of its seven bridges exactly once. This problem founded graph theory.

title: Kronecker's Jugendtraum (Hilbert's 12th)
description: Hilbert's 12th Problem asks to extend the Kronecker-Weber theorem: find explicit generators for all abelian extensions of number fields.

title: Kummer's Theorem on Binomial Coefficients
description: The p-adic valuation of C(n,k) equals the number of carries when adding k and n-k in base p. A beautiful connection between combinatorics and positional numeral systems.

title: Lagrange's Four Squares Theorem
description: Every natural number can be expressed as the sum of four squares, a profound result connecting number theory to quaternion algebra.

title: Lagrange's Theorem
description: For a finite group G and subgroup H, the order of H divides the order of G. Fundamental to group theory.

title: Law of Cosines
description: The generalization of the Pythagorean theorem to arbitrary triangles: c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab*cos(C), which reduces to the Pythagorean theorem when C = 90 degrees.

title: Laws of Large Numbers
description: The Laws of Large Numbers describe how sample averages converge to expected values. The Weak Law shows convergence in probability, while the Strong Law shows almost sure convergence.

title: Lebesgue Measure
description: Lebesgue measure extends the notion of length/area/volume to a rich class of sets, enabling the powerful Lebesgue integral that revolutionized analysis.

title: Legendre's Conjecture (Partial)
description: Legendre's conjecture states there's always a prime between n^2 and (n+1)^2. Verified with explicit witnesses for n = 1 to 20.

title: Leibniz's Series for Pi
description: The Leibniz formula for pi: the alternating series 1 - 1/3 + 1/5 - 1/7 + ... converges to pi/4.

title: L'Hopital's Rule
description: A fundamental technique for evaluating limits of indeterminate forms: if f(x)/g(x) approaches 0/0 or infinity/infinity, then the limit equals the limit of f'(x)/g'(x).

title: Liouville's Theorem on Transcendental Numbers
description: Liouville numbers are transcendental. This provides the first explicit construction of transcendental numbers via rational approximation bounds.

title: The Principle of Mathematical Induction
description: For any predicate P on natural numbers, if P(0) holds and P(n) implies P(n+1) for all n, then P(n) holds for all n. Peano's fifth axiom and the foundation of recursive proofs.

title: Mean Value Theorem
description: If f is continuous on [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b), there exists c where f'(c) = (f(b)-f(a))/(b-a).

title: Minkowski's Fundamental Theorem
description: A convex, centrally symmetric body with volume greater than 2^n contains a non-zero lattice point. Foundational for the geometry of numbers.

title: Morley's Theorem
description: The three angle trisectors of any triangle, taken in pairs, meet to form an equilateral triangle. A surprising result discovered in 1899.

title: Motivic Class of Genus 0 Maps to Flag Varieties
description: The motivic class of based rational maps from P¹ to flag varieties equals the class of GL_n times affine space in the Grothendieck ring of varieties.

title: Global Regularity for Navier-Stokes
description: A conditional regularity theorem for the Navier-Stokes Millennium Prize Problem. We identify the precise structural obstruction (scale-bridging concentration) and formulate the minimal Bubble Persistence hypothesis B′ under which all known tools close: B′ → Type I → ESŠ → regularity.

title: P vs NP Problem
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Can every problem whose solution can be verified quickly also be solved quickly?

title: Independence of the Parallel Postulate
description: Euclid's parallel postulate is independent of the other axioms of geometry. There exist consistent geometries (Euclidean and hyperbolic) that differ on this postulate.

title: Euler's Partition Theorem
description: The number of partitions of n into odd parts equals the number of partitions into distinct parts. A beautiful bijection in combinatorics.

title: Pascal's Hexagon Theorem
description: If a hexagon is inscribed in a conic section, the three pairs of opposite sides meet at collinear points. A fundamental result in projective geometry.

title: Solutions to Pell's Equation
description: Pell's equation x^2 - Dy^2 = 1 always has infinitely many solutions when D is not a perfect square, all generated from a unique fundamental solution.

title: Perfect Number Theorem
description: The Euclid-Euler theorem: a number is even and perfect if and only if it has the form 2^(p-1)(2^p - 1) where 2^p - 1 is a Mersenne prime.

title: Transcendence of Pi
description: Pi is transcendental: it is not a root of any polynomial with integer coefficients. This proves the impossibility of squaring the circle with ruler and compass.

title: Pick's Theorem
description: The area of a simple lattice polygon equals I + B/2 - 1, where I is the number of interior lattice points and B is the number of boundary lattice points.

title: The Number of Platonic Solids
description: There are exactly five Platonic solids (regular convex polyhedra): the tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron.

title: The Poincare Conjecture
description: Every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to the 3-sphere. Solved by Grigori Perelman in 2002-2003 using Ricci flow with surgery.

title: The Prime Number Theorem
description: The prime counting function pi(x) is asymptotically equivalent to x/ln(x). This describes the distribution of prime numbers among positive integers.

title: Divergence of Prime Reciprocals
description: The sum of reciprocals of all prime numbers diverges: 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/5 + 1/7 + 1/11 + ... = infinity.

title: Primitive Roots Modulo Primes
description: For any prime p, there are exactly φ(p-1) primitive roots modulo p. Uses the cyclic structure of (ℤ/pℤ)* and Mathlib's counting theorem.

title: Product of Segments of Chords
description: If two chords of a circle intersect at point P, then the product of the segments of one chord equals the product of the segments of the other: PA * PB = PC * PD.

title: Ptolemy's Theorem
description: For a cyclic quadrilateral, the product of diagonals equals the sum of products of opposite sides: AC·BD = AB·CD + BC·DA

title: Puiseux's Theorem
description: The field of Puiseux series (fractional power series) is algebraically closed. This provides a concrete algebraic closure of the Laurent series field.

title: Pythagorean Theorem
description: The most famous theorem in mathematics: in a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides. a² + b² = c²

title: Formula for Pythagorean Triples
description: All primitive Pythagorean triples (a,b,c) with a² + b² = c² are given by a = m² - n², b = 2mn, c = m² + n² for coprime m > n > 0.

title: Law of Quadratic Reciprocity
description: Gauss's 'golden theorem' of number theory: for distinct odd primes p and q, the Legendre symbols (p/q) and (q/p) are equal unless both p and q are congruent to 3 mod 4.

title: The Ramanujan Sum Fallacy
description: A demonstration of how Lean catches the famous fallacious 'proof' that 1+2+3+... = -1/12, showing why mathematical rigor matters.

title: Ramsey's Theorem
description: Frank Ramsey's foundational theorem in combinatorics: for any 2-coloring of the complete graph K_n with sufficiently large n, there exists a monochromatic clique.

title: Randomized MaxCut Approximation
description: A formal proof that a simple randomized algorithm achieves a 1/2-approximation for the NP-Complete Maximum Cut problem, using linearity of expectation.

title: The Riemann Hypothesis
description: A formalization of the Riemann Hypothesis, one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. We state RH precisely using Mathlib's zeta function, prove key equivalences (Robin's inequality, Mertens bound), and document partial results like Hardy's theorem on infinitely many zeros on the critical line.

title: Russell's 1+1=2
description: The legendary proof that 1+1=2, which famously took 362 pages in Principia Mathematica but is trivial in modern type theory.

title: Schroeder-Bernstein Theorem
description: If there exist injections f: A to B and g: B to A, then there exists a bijection between A and B. This establishes that cardinality is antisymmetric.

title: Solution of the Cubic Equation
description: Cardano's formula provides explicit radical solutions to cubic equations. The formula was discovered in the 16th century during the Italian mathematical renaissance.

title: Sophie Germain Primes
description: A prime p is a Sophie Germain prime if 2p+1 is also prime. We prove that all Sophie Germain primes greater than 3 must have the form 6k-1 (equivalently, p ≡ 5 mod 6).

title: Basic Lean Examples
description: A collection of simple example proofs demonstrating basic Lean tactics including non-negativity of squares and implication transitivity.

title: Square Root of 2 is Irrational (From Axioms)
description: A complete proof that sqrt(2) is irrational built from first principles, demonstrating the classical proof by contradiction with even/odd analysis.

title: Irrationality of Square Roots
description: The classic proof that √2 is irrational, generalized to show √n is irrational for any non-perfect-square n. Covers √2, √3, √5, √6, √7 and the general theorem.

title: Stirling's Formula
description: Stirling's approximation for factorials: n! ~ sqrt(2*pi*n) * (n/e)^n. The ratio approaches 1 as n goes to infinity.

title: Number of Subsets of a Set
description: A finite set with n elements has exactly 2^n subsets. This fundamental result connects set theory to binary counting.

title: Sum of kth Powers (Faulhaber's Formulas)
description: Closed-form formulas for sums of consecutive kth powers, including the remarkable identity that the sum of cubes equals the square of the sum.

title: Sylow's Theorems
description: The three Sylow theorems: existence of Sylow p-subgroups, their conjugacy, and counting constraints. Fundamental structure theorems for finite groups.

title: Szemeredi's Theorem (k=3 via Mathlib)
description: Dense subsets of natural numbers contain arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. The k=3 case (Roth's theorem) is fully proved using Mathlib's corners theorem chain.

title: Taylor's Theorem
description: A smooth function can be approximated by its Taylor polynomial, with explicit remainder terms (Lagrange and Cauchy forms).

title: Universality of Three-Place Identity
description: Tom Etter's Universality Theorem: three-place relative identity is foundationally adequate for all of mathematics, establishing mutual interpretability with ZF set theory.

title: Sum of Angles of a Triangle
description: The sum of the interior angles of a triangle equals 180° (π radians). One of the most fundamental results in Euclidean geometry.

title: The Triangle Inequality
description: The fundamental inequality stating that the sum of any two sides of a triangle exceeds the third side. For real numbers: |x + y| ≤ |x| + |y|.

title: Sum of Reciprocals of Triangular Numbers
description: The sum of reciprocals of triangular numbers equals 2: ∑(2/(n(n+1))) = 2. A beautiful telescoping series result.

title: Twin Primes in Special Forms
description: Twin prime pairs (p, p+2) where both are prime must have the form (6k-1, 6k+1) for p > 3. A structural theorem constraining where twin primes can occur.

title: Vieta's Formulas
description: Vieta's formulas relate polynomial coefficients to sums and products of roots. For x^2 - bx + c = 0 with roots r, s: r + s = b and r * s = c.

title: Wilson's Theorem
description: A natural number n > 1 is prime if and only if (n-1)! is congruent to -1 modulo n. A beautiful characterization connecting factorials and primality.

title: Wolstenholme's Theorem
description: For prime p >= 5, the binomial coefficient C(2p-1, p-1) = 1 (mod p^3). Verified computationally for p = 5, 7, 11, 13. Connected to harmonic number divisibility.

title: Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap
description: One of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. Prove that quantum Yang-Mills theory exists and has a positive mass gap.
